questions.text: A patient presented with glossitis and a glove and stocking pattern of neuropathy. On CBC - MCV is noticed to be 105fl. Which vitamin deficiency is most likely responsible for this clinical presentation?
questions.solution:
The clinical presentation, which includes glossitis and glove and stocking pattern neuropathy, is most consistent with Vitamin B12 deficiency.
This deficiency can result due to Pernicious anemia, which exhibits a variety of symptoms, including those mentioned.
Vitamin B12 deficiency can lead to a broad spectrum of symptoms, including neurological issues like peripheral neuropathy (notably in a glove and stocking pattern) due to improper myelin formation of nerves and gastrointestinal symptoms such as diarrhea.
Additionally, it can cause megaloblastic anaemia (resulting in increased MCV) and often associated with cheilitis and glossitis.

Other options- 
  • Option 1- Vitamin B1 deficiency causes Beri Beri. It presents with cardiomyopathy or peripheral neuropathy but not megaloblastic anemia.
  • Option 3- Folic acid deficiency can cause megaloblastic anemia but not peripheral neuropathy. 
  • Option 4- Vitamin B2 deficiency can cause angular glossitis but other features are not associated.

questions.text: A five-year-old female child has odd facial traits, an oversized head, corneal clouding, hepatosplenomegaly, a protruding abdomen, breathing problems caused by obstructive sleep apnea, and thickened heart valves. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• Peculiar facial features, enlarged head, hepatosplenomegaly, protuberant abdomen, breathing difficulty with obstructive sleep apnea, and cardiac valve thickening are suggestive of Mucopolysaccharidoses. 
  • Since the child is a female - it cannot be Hunter's disease since Hunter is inherited in an X-linked recessive manner. 
  • The likely diagnosis is Hurler's syndrome and it is characterized by a deficiency of alpha-L-iduronidase enzyme.
Other conditions:
  • Hunter’s disease (MPS II) also involves similar features, but it is usually more common in males and does not present with corneal clouding, which is often seen in Hurler's disease.
  • Fragile X syndrome typically presents with developmental delay and intellectual disability but does not commonly cause the physical symptoms listed above.
  • Tay-Sachs disease is characterized by neurodegeneration and progressive loss of motor skills, but it does not typically involve the physical symptoms described.


 

Reference- Nelson Essentials Of Pediatrics Edition 21 st Page No 811,812

questions.text: Researchers are studying the epidemiology of various diseases and their distribution patterns in rural and urban populations.  Which of the following conditions is LEAST likely to show a significant difference in incidence between these two populations?
questions.solution:
The correct answer is: 3. Mental illness

Mental illnesses, including depression, anxiety, schizophrenia, and bipolar disorder, occur across all populations, irrespective of urban or rural settings. While certain risk factors (such as stress, access to care, and social support) may vary, the overall incidence and prevalence of mental illness does not show a significant difference between urban and rural populations. The lifetime prevalence of psychiatric disorders is comparable in rural and urban communities, standing at 32% and 34%, respectively. 

Other options

  • Lung Cancer – More common in urban areas due to higher pollution levels, industrial exposure, and smoking prevalence.
  • Tuberculosis (TB) – More prevalent in urban settings due to overcrowding, poor sanitation, and increased transmission in dense populations. 
  • Chronic Bronchitis and COPD – Higher in Rural Areas.
Reference Gupta, Rajiv. Rural–Urban Divide in Mental Health Care in India: Bridging the Gaps. Indian Journal of Social Psychiatry 40(1):p 7-10, Jan–Mar 2024. | DOI: 10.4103/ijsp.ijsp_41_24

questions.text: An MRI technician explains the safety features of the MRI room to a patient.  What specific structure is essential for shielding the room from external electromagnetic radiation?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 2: Faraday cage.
 
  • A Faraday cage is a conductive enclosure used to shield the inner space from electromagnetic interference. In MR imaging, this type of structure provides radiofrequency shielding to the scanning room to minimize occurrence of interference-associated imaging artifact.
  • Faraday cage is a conductive box used to shield out stray electromagnetic interference i.e. it keeps external electrical noise out and keeps generated radiofrequency signal from the MR machine within the examination room.
  • Careful shielding of the MR room is essential to prevent contamination of weak signal arising from patient from extraneous signal at the same frequency.
  • The shield must encircle the entire room-walls, floor and ceiling.
Reference: Cheng J, Bell D, Gilcrease-Garcia B, et al. Faraday cage. Reference article, Radiopaedia.org (Accessed on 18 Sep 2024) https://doi.org/10.53347/rID-61562

questions.text: ART-treated HIV patient  is on treatment for migraine. After a few hours, her limbs feel cold, and her lower limbs' distal pulses are absent. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• Ergotism(aka St. Anthony's fire) is the result of ergot poisoning, which is traditionally brought on by consuming the alkaloids made by the fungus Claviceps purpurea
  • The fungus's ergotamine-ergocristine alkaloids cause vasoconstriction, which leads to dry gangrene
  • It affects the distal structures that have less blood flow, like the fingers and toes.
  • Desquamation or peeling, weak peripheral pulses, loss of peripheral feeling, edema, and eventually the death and loss of affected tissues are some of the symptoms.
  • Vasodilators are used to treat vasoconstriction.
Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 3584, 3590.

questions.text: Two radiologists independently interpret 200 chest X-rays for the presence of a specific finding. Their agreement is assessed using the Kappa statistic, which is calculated to be 0.71. How is this level of agreement generally interpreted?
questions.solution:
A Kappa statistic of 0.71 indicates good agreement between the two radiologists.

Here’s how Kappa values are generally interpreted:

  • 0 to 0.20: Poor agreement
  • 0.21 to 0.40: Fair agreement
  • 0.41 to 0.60: Moderate agreement
  • 0.61 to 0.80: Good/Substanial agreement
  • 0.81 to 1.00: Very good to perfect agreement

A Kappa value of 0.71 falls into the "Good Agreement" category, meaning that the two radiologists are in substantial agreement on their interpretations of the chest X-rays.

Reference: McHugh ML. Interrater reliability: the kappa statistic. Biochem Med (Zagreb). 2012;22(3):276-82. PMID: 23092060; PMCID: PMC3900052.

questions.text: A nephrologist is examining a urine sample from a patient with suspected renal parenchymal disease. They are looking for specific types of urinary casts, which are cylindrical structures formed within the renal tubules. Which type of urinary cast is most indicative of glomerulonephritis ?
questions.solution:
The correct answer is 1. RBC cast.

RBC (red blood cell) casts are highly indicative of glomerulonephritis, which is an inflammation of the glomeruli in the kidneys. These casts form when red blood cells leak into the tubules due to glomerular injury, such as in glomerulonephritis, and they take on the shape of the tubular lumen, resulting in the characteristic RBC casts. The presence of RBC casts is a strong diagnostic feature for glomerular diseases like acute glomerulonephritis.

Other options:

  • Coarse granular cast: These are often seen in acute tubular necrosis (ATN) or chronic kidney disease, but they are not as specific to glomerulonephritis.

  • Hyaline cast: These are non-specific and can be seen in normal urine or in conditions like dehydration or exercise, but they are not indicative of glomerulonephritis.

  • WBC cast: These are indicative of interstitial nephritis or infection (e.g., pyelonephritis), not glomerulonephritis.

So, the presence of RBC casts is most closely associated with glomerulonephritis.
 

Reference: Harrison’s Principals of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page No 2304.

questions.text: A male patient presents with a perineal injury. During surgical exploration, the surgeon identifies the bulbospongiosus muscle and posterior scrotal nerves. Which of the following structures is NOT typically found within the superficial perineal pouch?
questions.solution:
The Sphincter urethrae is not a component of the superficial perineal pouch. It's a component of the deep perineal pouch.  

Superficial Perineal Pouch 
It's the space between the perineal membrane and the deep membranous layer of superficial fascia. 

Boundaries of Superficial Perineal Pouch 
Inferior:  Membranous layer of the superficial fascia.
Superior: Perineal Membrane.
Lateral:  Ischiopubic rami.

Contents of Superficial Perineal Pouch 
  • Root(Crura) of penis/clitoris and muscles associated (Ischicavernous)
  • Bulb of penis/vestibule and muscles associated (Bulbospongiosus)
  • Corpus cavernosum and spongiosum
  • Ducts of bulbourethral(male)/greater vestibular glands(female)
  • Superficial Transverse perineal muscle
  • Branches of the internal pudendal artery (posterior scrotal/labial artery and vein
  • Artery to bulb (males)/vestibule (females)
  • Branches of the pudendal nerve(posterior scrotal/labial nerve)
Reference: Gray's Anatomy The Anatomical Basis Of Clinical Practice Edition 42 nd Page no 1256,1257

choices.text: 16mL*weight in kg* %TBSA with 8ml/kg in first 8 hours followed by 8mL/kg in rest 16 hours

questions.text: A burn victim arrives at the emergency department eight hours after suffering electrical burns affecting her abdomen, both legs, and her back. The burns cover a significant portion of her total body surface area (TBSA). Which Parkland formula variation should be used to calculate the appropriate fluid resuscitation volume for this patient within the first 24 hours post-burn?
questions.solution:
In the given scenario - the patient has "ELECTRICAL BURNS" - instead of 2ml/kg X TBSA- we will rather use 4 ml/kg * % TBSA fluid over 24 hours. Hence, option 2 is correct, not option 1.

According to ATLS 

  • Adult patients should receive an initial fluid resuscitation of 2 ml of Ringer Lactate* kg* %TBSA if they have deep partial or full thickness burns that cover more than 20% of their total body surface area (TBSA).
  • For patients with pediatric trauma and electrical burns, the target fluid resuscitation is calculated using 3 ml*kg*%TBSA and 4 ml*kg*%TBSA, respectively.
  • The fluid is administered in two portions: half over an eight-hour period, and the other half over a 16-hour period. 
  • In adults and hemodynamically healthy children, the rate of fluid administration should be titrated to effect using a target urine output of 0.5 ml/kg/hr to 1 ml/kg/hr, for electric burns it's 1-1.5mL/kg/hr. 


Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 668.

choices.text: Start TB treatment first, 2 weeks later ART
Start ART first and later start with ATT

questions.text: A patient is diagnosed with both tuberculosis (TB) and human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) infection. This co-infection requires careful management to optimize treatment outcomes. Which of the following approaches is the recommended strategy for initiating antiretroviral therapy (ART) and anti-tuberculosis treatment (ATT) in a patient with HIV and TB co-infection?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is option 3 - Start TB treatment first, 2 weeks later ART

Other options
  • Initiation of ART simulataneously with ATT (as given in option 1) or starting ART first (option4) may be associated with clinical deterioration due to immune reconstitution inflammatory syndrome (IRIS).
  • IRIS occurs when the immune system recovers after being suppressed, leading to an exaggerated inflammatory response against opportunistic infections or latent pathogens
  • These are most common in patients initiating both treatments at the same time, may occur as early as 1 week after initiation of ART therapy, and are seen more frequently in patients with advanced HIV disease
  • For these reasons it is recommended that initiation of ART be delayed in antiretroviral-naïve patients with CD4 counts >50 cells/μL until 2–4 weeks following the initiation of treatment for TB.
  • For patients with CD<50/microL - initiate ATT first and ART within 2 weeks
Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 1546, 1567.

questions.text: A patient with a history of hemolytic episodes after certain medications presents for evaluation. A blood smear reveals abnormal red blood cells. Which of the following best describes the RBCs of a G6PD deficient patient?
questions.solution:
In a patient with G6PD (glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase) deficiency, the correct description of the red blood cells (RBCs) is 4. Hemolyses in hypotonic saline.

G6PD deficiency leads to reduced production of NADPH, which is crucial for maintaining the integrity of the red blood cell membrane. As a result, these RBCs are more susceptible to oxidative stress and can undergo hemolysis more readily, especially in hypotonic saline. This means they would swell and burst in a dilute solution due to their compromised membrane stability.

The other options do not accurately describe the RBCs in G6PD deficiency:

  • 1. Mutated spectrin: This is more characteristic of conditions like hereditary spherocytosis.
  • 2. Spherical in shape: G6PD-deficient RBCs can be more prone to shape changes due to oxidative stress, but they are not specifically described as spherical. Spherical shape is seen in Hereditary Spherocytosis. 
  • 3. Resist hemolysis in saline: G6PD-deficient RBCs are actually more likely to hemolyze under oxidative stress conditions, including in hypotonic solutions.

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 640.

questions.text: An immunologist is analyzing the CD4 counts of 100 HIV-positive patients. The distribution of CD4 counts is presented in a histogram. Based on the distribution shown below, what is the mode of the CD4 count of this patient sample?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 4: 300-400
  • Frequency of first interval [ 100-200 ] = 2
  • Frequency of second interval [ 200-300] =7
  • Frequency of third interval [ 300-400] =10
  • Frequency of fourth interval [ 400-500] =3
  • Frequency of fifth interval [ 500-600] = 1
MODE = The interval having the highest frequency - 10
Therefore the mode is the distribution = 300-400

Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 975.

questions.text: During a neck dissection, the surgeon carefully identifies and protects the structures within the carotid sheath. Which of the following structures is NOT found within the carotid sheath?
questions.solution:
Sympathetic chain is not a content of carotid sheath.

Contents of carotid sheath are:
1. Internal jugular vein
2. Common carotid artery (in the lower part) and internal carotid artery (in the upper part)
3. Vagus nerve in between them.

Sympathetic chain lies behind posteriorly to the carotid sheath. 


 

Reference: Gray's Anatomy The Anatomical Basis Of Clinical Practice Edition 42 nd Page no. 577,578

questions.text: A 39-year-old man presents to the emergency department with a clean wound, without any significant laceration or tissue damage. He received his last tetanus toxoid (TT) vaccination 10 years ago. What is the appropriate tetanus prophylaxis for this patient, considering his wound characteristics and immunization history?
questions.solution:
The correct answer is: 1. Single dose of TT

For clean wounds, tetanus prophylaxis depends on the patient's vaccination history.

  • If the last TT dose was given ≥10 years ago → Give 1 booster dose of TT
  • If the last TT dose was given <10 years ago → No additional TT needed

In this case, the patient received his last TT vaccination 10 years ago, so he requires a single booster dose of TT to maintain immunity.

Other options

  • Option 2 - Full course of TT → Incorrect,  full course (3 doses) is only given to unvaccinated individuals.
  • Option 3 - TIG is only needed for dirty/severe wounds in unvaccinated individuals.
  • Option 4 - Since 10 years have passed, a booster is required for continued protection.
 



 

NOTE

Consider TIG in fully vaccinated patients who are immunocompromised, such as:

  • Patients with primary immunodeficiency, asplenia, or HIV infection

  • Patients undergoing cancer chemotherapy, corticosteroid, antimetabolite, or biologic immunomodulator therapy

Reference: Online course https://www.cdc.gov/vaccines/pubs/pinkbook/downloads/tetanus.pdf

choices.text: An external sign Of underlying invasive breast cancer

questions.text: A 60-year-old woman presents to her physician complaining of persistent burning, itching, and redness of her left nipple and areola. Clinical examination reveals eczematous changes and crusting of the nipple, as shown in the image. This presentation is consistent with Paget's disease of the breast, a rare form of breast cancer. Which of the following statements about Paget's disease of the breast is INCORRECT?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 4) S-100 antigen positive on immunostaining
 
  • The clinical evaluation and the image suggest Paget's disease of the breast, a rare form of breast cancer that affects the nipple and areola.
  • While Paget's disease of the breast is associated with underlying invasive breast cancer in most cases, immunostaining for S-100 antigen is typically negative in Paget's cells. Paget's disease shows positive immunostaining with carcinoembryonic antigen (CEA), while superficial spreading melanoma is positive for S-100 antigen.
  • Other accurate statements include external signs of underlying invasive cancer, presentation with a mass in more than 50% of cases.
  • Depending on the type and extent of underlying malignancy, it can be treated with mastectomy.


Fig: Nipple erosion in early Paget’s disease

Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 924.

questions.text: A 50-year-old woman presents with abnormal uterine bleeding, experiencing heavy and prolonged menstrual periods. What is the most appropriate next step in the management of this patient's abnormal uterine bleeding?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 3. Endometrial aspiration and cervical curettage

This is done to identify the pathology and rule out endometrial cancer. 
More than or equal to 45 year old women with atypical uterine bleeding(AUB)-
1. Rule out pregnancy
2. Transvaginal USG
3. Endometrial sampling 

Other close option- 
Progesterone is given for 6 months as treatment of endometrial hyperplasia. 





Reference: Shaw's Textbook of Gynaecology, 17th edition, Page no 183, 185.

questions.text:
A radiologist is reviewing a series of abdominal X-rays and describing characteristic radiological signs associated with different gastrointestinal conditions. Match each radiological sign (a-d) with its corresponding diagnosis (1-4):
 
a. Rat tail sign 1. TB
b. String sign 2. Pneumoperitoneum
c. Inverted umbrella 3. Pyloric stenosis
d. Football sign 4. CA esophagus
questions.solution:
• The Rat's tail sign refers to abrupt tapering of the inferior esophagus on barium swallow study seen in Carcinoma esophagus. 

 
  • The String sign refers to luminal narrowing with elongated pylorus with a narrow lumen seen in Pyloric stenosis

 
  • The Fleischner sign (also known as the inverted umbrella sign), refers to a widely gaping, thickened, patulous ileocecal valve and a narrowed, ulcerated terminal ileum associated with tuberculous involvement of the ileocecum.

 
  • The Football sign is seen in cases of massive pneumoperitoneum, where the abdominal cavity is outlined by gas from a perforated viscus.


Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th edition, Page no 1122.

questions.text: A pharmacologist is lecturing on the clinical use of nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs). Which of the following statements about NSAIDs is FALSE?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Used in Neuropathic Pain.
  • NSAIDs are helpful for nociceptive pain (they inhibit COX which produces Prostaglandins which mediates nociceptive pain) but cannot relieve neuropathic pain as the physiologic process behind both are different.
  • NSAIDs do not affect the tenderness induced by direct application of PGs, but block the pain sensitizing mechanism induced by bradykinin, TNFα, interleukins (ILs) and other analgesic substances primarily by inhibiting COX-2. This constitutes the peripheral component of the analgesic action of NSAIDs. They are, therefore, more effective against inflammation associated pain.
  • Drugs like Gabapentin/SSRIs are used for Neuropathic pain.
Option 2 and 3 are correct regarding NSAIDs interaction: NSAIDs decrease prostaglandin production in affarent arterioles.  Renal effects of NSAIDs become significant in those with CHF, hypovolemia, hepatic cirrhosis, renal disease and in patients receiving diuretics or antihypertensives. In them Na+ retention and edema can occur; diuretic and antihypertensive drug effects are blunted.

Option 4 is correct as NSAIDs have been marketed in topical formulations (mostly as gels) for application over painful muscles or joints.

It is presumed that the drug would penetrate to the subjacent tissues attaining high concentrations in the affected muscles/joints, while maintaining low blood levels. Some Topical Preparations are Diclofenac gel 1%, Ibuprofen 10% etc.

Extra Edge-
Types of Pain and drugs used-
1. Mechanical Pain- NSAIDs
2. Visceral pain- Anticholinergics, drotaverine
3. Neuropathic pain- Gabapentin, Pregabalin, Methylcobalamine
4. Psychological pain- Antidepressants and antipsychotics

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 210.

questions.text: A hematologist is explaining the coagulation cascade to medical students. They are discussing the different pathways involved in blood clotting. Which of the following clotting factors is a key component of the extrinsic pathway of coagulation?
questions.solution:
• Factor VII (OPTION 1) is a key component of the extrinsic pathway of coagulation.
• The prothrombin time (PT) assay evaluates the function of the proteins involved in the extrinsic and common pathway, which includes Factors VII, X, V, II (prothrombin), and fibrinogen.
• Factors VIII, IX, and XI are involved in the intrinsic pathway of coagulation.
• Factor VIII, in particular, plays a critical role in the intrinsic pathway, and its function is assessed through the partial thromboplastin time (PTT) assay.




Reference - https://www.osmosis.org/answers/coagulation-cascade

questions.text: A 1-month-old child is brought to the OPD for consultation regarding an empty scrotal sac. On examination B/L inguinal masses are palpable. What is the next step of management in this child?
questions.solution:
• Since the infant in the clinical scenario is one month old and the normal age at which testis can fall on their own is six months, waiting and monitoring for spontaneous descent over the next six months would be the best course of action.
  • The best time to do orchidopexy is before the boy is before 12 months old.
  • Orchidopexy is performed to prevent the following issues:
1.Infertility
2. Herna
3. Cancer
4. Infection
5. Torsion

Reference: Bailey and Love's Short practice of Surgery 27th edition page no 1499

questions.text: A concerned parent brings their toddler to the pediatrician after noticing a few drops of bright red blood on the child's stool and toilet paper. There is no associated pain or other symptoms. What is the most likely cause of this rectal bleeding in a toddler?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Juvenile Rectal Polyp
 
  • Juvenile rectal polyps are the most common cause of passage of a few drops of blood per rectum in a toddler.
  • They are benign, mushroom-like growths that occur in the lining of the rectum.
  • They typically cause mild rectal bleeding but can also cause discomfort, pain, and bright red blood in the stool or on toilet paper. Other causes of rectal bleeding in toddlers include infections, anal fissures, certain medications, or even foreign bodies in the rectum.
  • This is a bright red, glistening pedunculated sphere (‘cherry tumor’) that is found in infants and children that may persist into adult life.
Other options- 
  • Adenoid Polyposis coli and piles are uncommon in toddler.
  • Rectal ulcer is also uncommon in toddlers and is associated with IBD. 
Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 1403.

questions.text: A surgical resident is studying the anatomy of the thoracic wall, specifically the arrangement of the intercostal neurovascular bundles. Which intercostal space has a different arrangement of vein, artery, and nerve compared to the typical pattern observed in other intercostal spaces?
questions.solution:
• Regular vein, artery and nerve ('VAN') arrangement is not present in the first intercostal space.
  • The first intercostal vessels and nerve pass along the lower surface between intercostal intimi and costal pleura with arrangements of nerve, artery and vein from above downwards.
 

Reference: Gray's Anatomy The Anatomical Basis of Clinical Practice, 41st Edition Page no 943-945 and 979

questions.text: An 8-month-old infant presents to a pediatrician for a well-child check-up. Upon examination, the pediatrician notes clinical signs suggestive of vitamin A deficiency, including night blindness and dry eyes. What is the appropriate single dose of vitamin A supplementation for this infant, considering their age and the suspected deficiency?
questions.solution:
• For an 8-month-old infant exhibiting clinical symptoms of a vitamin A deficiency, the recommended oral dosage is 100,000 IU.
Treatment of vitamin A insufficiency in children:
  1.  <6 months - Give orally - 50,000 IU on day 0,1 and day 14
  2.  6-12 months - Give orally - 1,00,000 (1 lakh) IU on day 0,1 and day 14
  3.  >12 months - Give orally - 2,00,000 (2lakh) IU on day 0,1 and day 14
Reference: Comprehensive opthalmology by AK khurana 6th edition page no 469

questions.text: What does the illustration below represent?
questions.solution:
The given image represents the symbol of radiation hazard.


There is no specific dedicated symbol for bioterrorism. 

Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 920.

questions.text: A patient with dysphagia undergoes a surgical procedure involving the division of a specific muscle. What condition is Heller's myotomy used to treat?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 2: Achalasia cardia
 
  • Heller's myotomy is a surgical procedure used to treat achalasia cardia, a motility disorder of the esophagus characterized by impaired relaxation of the lower esophageal sphincter.
  • During Heller's myotomy, the muscle fibers of the lower esophageal sphincter are cut to relieve the obstruction and improve esophageal emptying
  • This involves cutting the muscle of the lower esophagus and gastric cardia
  • Typically, anterior myotomy is performed for at least 6 cm proximally at the esophageal side and 2–3 cm distally into the gastric cardia.
  • Transabdominal or transthoracic approaches have been advocated. Currently, the standard procedure is a laparoscopic approach. The major complication is GORD - Gastro-oesophageal reflux, which can occur in up to 40% of patients. The addition of a partial fundoplication (anterior Dor or posterior Toupet) has been shown to be effective in reducing the incidence of GORD.



Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 1123.

questions.text: What is the finding of the X ray given below?
questions.solution:
Correct option is 1: Congenital scoliosis.

In the given chest and abdomen radiograph, the dorsal spine shows lateral curvature with convexity towards left in upper part and towards right in lower part which is suggestive of scoliosis. This along with presence of hemivertebra in dorsal spine makes the diagnosis in favour of congenital scoliosis. 






Reference: Apley & Solomon's System of Orthopaedics and Trauma, 10th edition, Page no 499-501.

questions.text: A gastroenterologist is reviewing a colonoscopy report that mentions the presence of pseudopolyps. In which of the following inflammatory bowel diseases are pseudopolyps most characteristically observed?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Ulcerative colitis 
  • Pseudo polyps are inflammatory polypoid lesions that can be seen in the colon and rectum.
  • They are typically observed in the setting of chronic inflammation of the gastrointestinal mucosa.
  • Ulcerative colitis, an inflammatory bowel disease, is one of the conditions in which pseudo polyps are commonly seen.
  • Pseudo polyps are formed due to the regeneration of the mucosal epithelium in areas of ulceration and destruction.
Crohn’s vs ulcerative colitis:



Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 802.

choices.text: H. pylori infection, Silver stain, Gram-negative coccobacilli

questions.text: A 30-year-old male patient presents with complaints of heartburn and difficulty swallowing. An upper gastrointestinal endoscopy reveals a suspicious lesion in the esophagus. A biopsy is taken, and the histopathological examination shows specialized columnar epithelium with goblet cells, indicative of intestinal metaplasia. What is the most likely diagnosis based on these findings? What special stain can confirm this diagnosis, and what specific histological feature would you look for?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 4) Barrett’s esophagus, mucin stain, dysplasia
 
  • The histological picture of the esophagus shows intestinal-type epithelium with goblet cells, characteristic of Barrett's esophagus.
  • Mucin stain helps to better define the extent of dysplasia and rule out malignant transformation.
  • Diagnosis of Barrett esophagus requires endoscopic evidence of metaplastic columnar mucosa above the gastroesophageal junction. Microscopically, intestinal-type metaplasia is seen as replacement of the squamous esophageal epithelium with goblet cells.
  • Goblet cells are diagnostic of Barrett esophagus and have distinct mucous vacuoles that stain pale blue and impart the shape of a wine goblet to the remaining cytoplasm.
  • Non-goblet columnar cells, such as gastric-type foveolar cells, may also be present, but there is not universal agreement as to whether they are sufficient for the diagnosis.
Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 761.

questions.text: A patient presents with symptoms of metabolic poisoning after ingesting contaminated food. Lab tests indicate a blockage in a key energy-producing pathway within the mitochondria by a compound called flouroacetate. Which metabolic process is most likely inhibited?
questions.solution:
• Fluoroacetate is metabolized in the body into fluorocitrate, a toxic compound that inhibits the enzyme aconitase.
  • Aconitase is critical in the tricarboxylic acid (TCA) cycle (also known as the Krebs cycle or citric acid cycle), where it catalyzes the conversion of citrate to isocitrate.
  • When aconitase is blocked, the TCA cycle cannot proceed effectively, halting the production of energy intermediates like NADH and FADH2, which are essential for ATP generation via oxidative phosphorylation. Since this blockage occurs directly within the TCA cycle, energy production is disrupted downstream as well, but the primary site of inhibition is the TCA cycle itself.

Reference: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry, 31st Edition, Page no 158

questions.text: A neurologist is discussing the characteristics of Guillain-Barre syndrome with a medical student. The neurologist emphasizes the key clinical and pathological features of this autoimmune neuropathy. Which of the following statements about Guillain-Barre syndrome is INCORRECT?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 3: Descending paralysis
 
  • Guillain-Barré syndrome (GBS) is an autoimmune disorder affecting the peripheral nervous system.
  • GBS manifests as a rapidly evolving areflexic motor paralysis with or without sensory disturbance. The usual pattern is an ascending paralysis  (not descending) that may be first noticed as rubbery legs.
  • It is characterized by inflammation and demyelination of nerves, leading to weakness, numbness, and tingling in the limbs.
  • GBS typically follows an ascending pattern; it usually starts in the feet and hands and moves up the body.
  • Cranial nerves can also be affected, leading to issues with facial, eye, and mouth control.
  • GBS is both inflammatory and demyelinating in nature, involving damage to the protective sheath surrounding nerves.
Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 3501.

questions.text: An otolaryngologist is evaluating a patient with a tumor arising from the olfactory mucosa within the nasal cavity. This type of tumor, characterized by its origin in the specialized olfactory neuroepithelium, is known as:
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 4: Esthesioneuroblastoma

Olfactory nasal mucosa tumor is also known as Esthesioneuroblastoma or Olfactory placode tumour.
Arises from the olfactory epithelium located in the roof of the nose.

Other options- 

  • Nasal Glioma: This is a benign congenital tumor that arises from ectopic glial tissue, usually near the nasal bridge, but it is not associated with the olfactory mucosa.
  • Adenoid cystic carcinoma: A malignancy that often affects the salivary glands, though it can occur in the nasal cavity, it does not arise from the olfactory neuroepithelium.
  • Nasopharyngeal carcinoma: A type of cancer that arises in the nasopharynx (the upper part of the throat behind the nose), but it is not associated with the olfactory mucosa.

Reference : P L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck surgery , 7th Edition- page 417,229

questions.text: A pharmacologist is discussing neurotransmitters and their chemical structures. The image depicts the molecular structure of an important neurotransmitter involved in mood regulation, sleep, and appetite. What is the chemical name for this neurotransmitter?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: 5-hydroxytryptamine (5-HT)
 
  • Serotonin is synthesized from the amino acid tryptophan by a two step process as shown below and the chemical name of Serotonin is 5- Hydroxytryptamine.

 
  • Synthesized in argentaffin cells in intestine, platelets and brain.
  • It functions as neurotransmitter which is responsible for vasoconstriction, mood regulation and gastrointestinal tract motility.
  • Its levels are significantly elevated in neuroendocrine tumors and leads to symptoms (known as Serotonin Syndrome) such as intermittent diarrhea, cutaneous flushing, sweating and fluctuating hypertension.
Reference: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry, 32nd Edition, Page no 310.

questions.text: A biochemist is studying a variety of enzymes involved in different metabolic pathways. Which of the following enzymes does NOT typically participate in oxidation-reduction reactions?
questions.solution:
Correct option is (2) Hydrolases. Hydrolases are not involved in oxidation-reduction reactions and do not belong to the family of oxidoreductases.
Hydrolases are a class of enzymes that catalyze the hydrolysis of various chemical bonds, such as ester, peptide, and glycosidic bonds, by breaking them down with the addition of water. 

Enzymes involved in oxidation-reduction reactions are called oxidoreductases.

Enzymes are classified into six classes.

1. Oxidoreductases - Catalyze oxidations and reductions.
2. Transferases - Catalyze the transfer of moieties such as glycosyl,methyl,or phosphoryl.
3. Hydrolases - Catalyze the hydroytic cleavage of C-C,C-N and other covalent bonds.
4. Lyases -  Catalyze cleavage of C-C,C-O,C-N and other covalent bonds by atom elimination,generating double bonds.
5. Isomerases-  Catalyze geometric or structural changes within a molecule.
6. Ligases - Catalyze the joining together(ligation) of two molecules in reaction coupled to the hydrolysis of ATP.

Reference: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry, 31st Edition, Page no 57.

questions.text: A glaucoma patient on systemic beta blockers needs additional ocular hypotensive therapy. Which of the following medications should be AVOIDED in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Levobunolol
  •  Levobunolol is a non- selective beta blocker used as eye drops in open angle glaucoma.
  • All of the following(Brominidine/Dorzolamide/PGE Analog) can be given to the patient of glaucoma, who is being treated with systemic beta blocker, except levobunolol.
  • Levobunolol should not be used in the patients on systemic beta blocker since it may exacerbate the negative effects of systemic beta-blockers in  these patients like bradycardia, bronchospasm, etc.
Other options- 
  • Brimonidine: This is an alpha-2 adrenergic agonist, which works by decreasing aqueous humor production and increasing uveoscleral outflow. It does not have the same risks as beta blockers and is generally safe to use in combination.
  • Dorzolamide: This is a carbonic anhydrase inhibitor that reduces the production of aqueous humor in the eye. It can be used safely with beta blockers.
  • Prostaglandin analogs (e.g., latanoprost, bimatoprost): These increase the outflow of aqueous humor and are also safe to use with beta blockers.
Reference: Goodman & Gilman’s the Pharmacological Basis of Therapeutics, 14th edition, Page No 1461.

questions.text: A young girl is brought to the pediatrician by her parents because she constantly dribbles urine. She also voids normally at regular intervals. The parents report that she has never achieved complete bladder control since birth, experiencing continuous urinary incontinence. What is the most likely diagnosis in this scenario, considering the girl's history of constant dribbling despite normal voiding?
questions.solution:
Case of ectopic ureter as the patient has continuous dribbling of urine.
  • IVU can be used for investigation
  • Re-implantation of the ectopic ureter is the definitive treatment.

Other options

Option 2 
Ureterocele is Incorrect
  • Ureterocoele is a cystic dilation of the distal ureter, usually within the bladder.
  • Presents with urinary obstruction, UTIs, and voiding difficulties, not constant dribbling.

Option 3 
Posterior Urethral Valves (PUV) is Incorrect. It cccurs only in males, due to obstruction at the urethra.Causes poor urinary stream, bladder distension, recurrent UTIs, and hydronephrosis, not constant dribbling with normal voiding

Option 4
Vesicoureteral Reflux (VUR) → Incorrect. It causes recurrent UTIs, hydronephrosis, and kidney damage. Does not cause continuous dribbling of urine. 

Reference:Nelson textbook of Pediatrics 21st edition Page no 2796, 2797, 2805-2807

questions.text: A pharmacist is calculating the appropriate dose of vancomycin for a patient with a serious infection. They are using a nomogram to determine the optimal dosing regimen based on the patient's renal function and other factors. Which nomogram is commonly used for vancomycin dosing?
questions.solution:
• The Matzke nomogram is utilized for determining vancomycin dosing.
  • It provides dosing intervals from 0.5 to 12 days, depending on creatinine clearance (CL) values ranging from 0 to 120 mL/min. This tool helps establish the initial empiric dose and interval for intravenous (IV) vancomycin in hospitalized adults who are not undergoing hemodialysis.
  • However, it is not suitable for patients with highly variable vancomycin pharmacokinetics, including critically ill individuals, those with severe burn injuries (over 20% of body surface), patients with rapidly changing renal function, pregnant women, individuals with liver failure or ascites, those at extreme weights, recent transplant recipients, and cystic fibrosis patients.
  • The Rumack-Matthew nomogram evaluates potential hepatotoxicity based on serum acetaminophen concentration relative to the time elapsed since ingestion, after a single acute dose of acetaminophen.

Reference: Rybak, M J, and S C Boike. “Individualized adjustment of vancomycin dosage: comparison with two dosage nomograms.” Drug intelligence & clinical pharmacy vol. 20,1 (1986): 64-8. https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/3943460/

choices.text: Sunflower cataract is caused by Wilson's disease
Christmas tree cataract is caused by Myotonic Dystrophy
Oil-drop cataract is always caused by Diabetes

questions.text: The following is not true about the causes of cataracts
questions.solution:
Correct option is 4: Oil-drop cataract is caused by Diabetes.
 
  • Oil-drop cataract refers to the presence of yellowish or brownish, oil-like droplets in the lens. It is not specifically caused by diabetes.
  • The most common cause of oil-drop cataract is galactosemia.
  • In galactosemia, the accumulation of galactose and its metabolites in the lens can lead to the formation of oil-drop opacities.
  • While diabetes can contribute to the development of certain types of cataracts, such as posterior subcapsular cataracts and snowflake cataracts, it is not associated with oil-drop cataracts.



Reference: Comprehensive Ophthalmology by AK Khurana, 7th edition, Page no 193, 200.

questions.text: During a routine eye exam, an ophthalmologist uses a direct ophthalmoscope to visualize the patient's retina. By what factor is the image magnified through this instrument?
questions.solution:
Correct option is 3: 15 times.
 
  • When using a direct ophthalmoscope, the image of the fundus is magnified approximately 15 times.
  • This magnification enables a closer examination of the internal structures of the eye, such as the retina, blood vessels, and optic nerve.
  • A magnification of approximately 15 times provides a clear and detailed view, aiding in the diagnosis and assessment of various eye conditions.
Direct Ophthalmoscopy:
  • The most commonly practiced method for routine fundus examination.
  • Direct ophthalmoscopy should be performed in a semi-darkroom and the patient's right eye should be examined by the right eye of the observer and the patient's left eye with the observer's left eye.



Reference: Parsons’ Diseases of the Eye, 23rd edition, Page no 115, 547.

questions.text:
A patient presents with severe vomiting and diarrhea and has orthostatic hypotension. What metabolic abnormalities would you expect in this patient?

A. Hypokalemia
B. Hypochloremia
C. Metabolic alkalosis
D. Respiratory alkalosis
questions.solution:
The correct option is (3)A,B,C - A. Hypokalemia, B. Hypochloremia C. Metabolic alkalosis

The clinical scenario describes a patient with a history of vomiting and diarrhea, now presenting with orthostatic hypotension, indicating dehydration and extracellular fluid volume contraction. This triggers activation of the renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system (RAAS).

As aldosterone levels rise, it leads to increased excretion of hydrogen (H+) and potassium (K+) in the distal tubule of the kidneys, resulting in hypokalemia and metabolic alkalosis. The alkalosis is further aggravated by angiotensin II, which stimulates the Na+/H+ exchanger in the proximal convoluted tubule, increasing the reabsorption of sodium (Na+) and bicarbonate (HCO3-).

Hypochloremia arises from the loss of hydrochloric acid (HCl) due to vomiting and is perpetuated by renal chloride (Cl+) loss, which accompanies increased bicarbonate reabsorption.

In metabolic alkalosis, the body‘s compensatory response is respiratory acidosis, not respiratory alkalosis. This occurs through hypoventilation, which leads to an increase in arterial carbon dioxide (PaCO2) levels.

Thus Hypokalemic Hypochloremic Metabolic Alkalosis is seen. 
 

Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page no 365 .

questions.text: A nephrologist is evaluating a patient with polyuria and polydipsia. Which of the following conditions specifically involves impaired function of aquaporin channels, leading to this condition?
questions.solution:
Nephrogenic Diabetes Insipidus.

Nephrogenic Diabetes insipidus is a disorder caused by the impaired function of aquaporins, which are proteins that form channels in cell membranes, allowing water to move in and out of cells.

In diabetes insipidus, aquaporins are either missing or malfunctioning, preventing the proper regulation of water entering cells. As a result, too much water enters cells, leading to excessive urination and thirst.

This occurs because the kidneys’ ability to reabsorb water is impaired, reducing the concentration of solutes in the body. Consequently, the body must expel an excessive amount of water through urination to maintain solute balance.

Thus, the impaired function of aquaporins plays a crucial role in the development of diabetes insipidus due to their essential function in regulating water movement in and out of cells.

Other options- 

  • Liddle syndrome: A genetic disorder that leads to increased sodium reabsorption in the kidneys, causing hypertension and hypokalemia, but does not affect aquaporin channels.
  • Cystic fibrosis: A genetic disorder affecting the CFTR channel, primarily causing respiratory and digestive issues. It can cause electrolyte imbalances but does not directly impair aquaporin function.
  • Barter syndrome: A condition affecting renal salt handling, leading to hypokalemia, metabolic alkalosis, and polyuria, but it does not specifically involve impaired aquaporin channels.

Reference- Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology Edition 26 th Page no 675

questions.text: A pregnant woman undergoes routine coagulation studies. Which clotting factor is typically DECREASED during pregnancy?
questions.solution:
• During Pregnancy, the hemostasis tends to change towards hypercoagulability. (in order to decrease blood loss at the time of delivery).
  • Most coagulation factors/fibrinogen levels increase during pregnancy but Factor XI and XIII are the only factors that decrease.

Reference: DC Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics 9th Edition Page no 46 .

questions.text: A cardiologist is considering treatment options for a patient with pulmonary hypertension. They are looking for a drug that specifically targets the Rho-kinase pathway, which plays a role in vascular smooth muscle contraction. Which of the following drugs is a Rho-kinase inhibitor, used in the treatment of pulmonary hypertension?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Fasudil 
 
  • Fasudil is an inhibitor of smooth muscle Rho kinase and reduces coronary/pulmonary vasospasm. In clinical trials in patients with CAD, it has improved performance in stress tests. It is used in angina pectoris.
  • Fasudil appears to reduce pulmonary artery pressure in PAH(relaxing pumonary artery spasm)

Other options

Option 2 Ranolazine is a novel antianginal drug primarily acts by inhibiting a late Na+ current (late INa) in the myocardium which indirectly facilitates Ca2+ entry through Na+/Ca2+ exchanger.

Option 3 Amiloride block ENaCs in the luminal membrane of principal cells in late distal tubules and collecting ducts by binding to a site in the channel pore.

Option 4 Nicorandil is a dual mechanism antianginal drug activates ATP sensitive K+ channels (KATP) in smooth muscle membrane thereby hyperpolarizing and relaxing it.

Reference: Basic & Clinical Pharmacology, Bertram G. Katzung, 14th edition, Page No 313.

questions.text: A patient receiving antiretroviral therapy develops abdominal pain, nausea, and vomiting. Lab results show elevated amylase and lipase. Which medication is most likely responsible for these findings?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 4) Didanosine

Didanosine is not used anymore because it causes pancreatitis.

Anti-retro viral drugs and their side effects




Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 862.

choices.text: The middle valve corresponds to the middle convex fold to the Right
The upper valve corresponds to peritoneal reflections
The valves contain all three layers of muscle wall

questions.text: Which of the following claims regarding "Valves of Houston" is correct?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 4: Valves disappear after mobilization of Rectum
 
  • The valves of Houston are semilunar folds of the rectal wall that are formed by the muscularis propria of the rectum.
  • The muscularis propria is a layer of smooth muscle that forms the wall of the rectum.
  • During mobilization of the rectum, the muscularis propria is separated from the surrounding tissue. This separation results in the disappearance of the valves of Houston.

Other options: -
  • Middle valve corresponds to the middle convex fold to left.
  • The middle valve corresponds to peritoneal reflection.

Reference-:https://www.britannica.com/science/rectum#ref784333

questions.text: Goldenhar's syndrome is associated with the abnormal development of which of the following?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: First and Second Branchial Arches 

GOLDENHAR SYNDROME:
  • Goldenhar syndrome , a rare congenital defect is also known as OCULO AURICULAR VERTEBRAL SPECTRUM.
  • It is associated with anomalous development of the first and second branchial arch.
CLINICAL FEATURES
  • Incomplete development of the ear, nose, soft palate, lip, mandible (usually on one side )
  • Limbal Dermoids
  • Lipodermoid Tumours
  • Preauricular skin tags
  • Anotia, Microtia
  • Strabismus
  • Microphthalmia
  • Eyelid colobomas
  • Vertebral anomalies ( scoliosis, hemivertebrae)

Reference-https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3881767/

choices.text: Drop in fetal heart rate to less than 90 bpm for 60 sec
Drop in fetal heart rate to less than 110 bpm for 60 sec
Drop in fetal heart rate to less than 100 bpm for 60 sec
Drop in fetal heart rate to less than 60 bpm for 60 sec

questions.text: An obstetrician is monitoring fetal heart rate during labor.Baseline HR is 120BPM. They observe a pattern of significant variable decelerations, which are abrupt drops in fetal heart rate. Which of the following criteria defines a significant variable deceleration, indicating potential fetal distress?
questions.solution:
Variable Deceleration
Abrupt decrease in FHR of > 15 beats per minute measured from the most recently determined baseline rate The onset of deceleration to nadir is less than 30 seconds. The deceleration lasts   > 15 seconds and less than 2 minutes

Significant variable decelerations
A type of fetal heart rate (FHR) abnormality, are defined as variable decelerations that reach a nadir more than 60 beats per minute (BPM) below the baseline or reach a nadir of less than 60 BPM, regardless of baseline, and last longer than 60 seconds.

In the given scenario, the baseline FHR is 120bpm. So a drop to less than 60bpm for more than 60 seconds would considered as Significant variable deceleration.

Reference: DC Dutta's Textbook of Obstetrics, 8th edition, Page no 693.

questions.text: Which one of the following accurately describes a typical oral glucose tolerance test?
questions.solution: Reference-Williams Obstetrics 26th edition Page no 1079

questions.text: A 9-year-old girl is brought to the neurology clinic by her parents, who describe frequent episodes of the child staring blankly into space, sometimes accompanied by chewing movements. They also report a decline in her school performance and concerns about her daydreaming. During these episodes, the girl maintains her posture and does not exhibit any generalized tonic-clonic movements. An electroencephalogram (EEG) reveals characteristic 3-Hz spike-and-wave discharges. What is the first-line medication for managing this child's condition?
questions.solution:
The history of lip smacking and staring blankly into space points towards absence seizures.
Absence seizures are identified by the generalized symmetric 3 Hz spike-and-wave pattern seen in the EEG. Sodium valproate is the first-choice antiepileptic medication for treating this condition.

The only two FDA-approved first-line antiepileptic medications for absence seizures are ethosuximide and valproic acid.

Reference: Harrisons principles of internal medicine 19th edition page no 2543.

choices.text: Change atenolol and thiazide to calcium channel blocker and ACE inhibitor and add bisacodyl for constipation
Change imipramine and haloperidol to fluoxetine and risperidone and add bisacodyl for constipation
Only add bisacodyl for constipation and continue rest of the medications
Discontinue all her medications and start her on steroids

questions.text: A 86-year-old woman arrived at the clinic with acute constipation. She has just experienced depression. She is also complaining of feeling dizzy on standing up which is marked by a fall in BP. She is taking imipramine, haloperidol, atenolol and thiazide. What is the management's best course of action going forward?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Change imipramine and haloperidol to fluoxetine and risperidone and add bisacodyl for constipation

Considering the symptoms given in the problem, imipramine and haloperidol must be changed to fluoxetine and risperidone and add bisacodyl for constipation.
 
  • This patient's postural hypotension(feeling dizzy on getting up) is most likely caused by imipramine's alpha blocking and its interactions with thiazides.
  • She also has Imipramine's anticholinergic side effects, like constipation. Imipramine, a TCA, must thus be stopped, and Fluoxetine, an SSRI, together with a laxative to treat any existing constipation, should be begun.  
  • Additionally, because Haloperidol and other conventional antipsychotics also have anticholinergic adverse effects, she should begin taking the atypical antipsychotic Risperidone.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 485.

questions.text: A pediatrician is developing a treatment plan for a child diagnosed with pulmonary tuberculosis. According to standard guidelines, what is the recommended drug regimen for treating pulmonary TB in children, including the duration of each phase?
questions.solution:
• Children with pulmonary tuberculosis are treated with the 2HRZE + 4HRE regimen, which is split into two stages:
  • Intensive Phase:  It spans 8 weeks (2 months). The youngster receives the following treatment throughout this period: ethambutol (E), pyrazinamide (Z), rifampicin (R), and isoniazid (H).
  • Phase of Continuation: It is spread over 16 weeks (4 months). During this stage, pyrazinamide (Z) is stopped but isoniazid (H), rifampicin (R), and ethambutol (E) are kept up.
  • Under this regimen, children are treated based on six weight bands. Pediatric weight bands are used for who weigh less than 39 kg and are up to 18 years old. 
  • Steroids: Corticosteroids are generally not part of the routine treatment for uncomplicated pulmonary TB in children. They may be considered in specific situations, such as severe forms of TB (e.g. TB meningitis) or certain airway complications. Therefore, options 3 and 4 are generally not the standard first-line treatment for uncomplicated pulmonary TB.
Reference
1.Goodman & Gillman's The Pharmacological Basis Of Therapeutics - 14th Edition - Page 1279,1280
2.Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine - 27th Edition - Page 221

questions.text: An ophthalmologist is examining a patient with a suspected fungal corneal ulcer. The patient presents with several characteristic features. Which of the following clinical findings is NOT typically associated with a fungal corneal ulcer?
questions.solution:
Correct option is 4: Ulcus Serpens.

A fungal corneal ulcer is usually caused by trauma with vegetative or organic matter. The corneal ulcer appears dry with delicate feathery finger-like extensions. 
Ulcus serpens is a hypopyon corneal ulcer caused by pneumococcus. Hence not seen in this condition.
  • Option 1: The immune ring of Wessely is formed by infiltrates of stroma in a circular fashion in fungal corneal ulcers. It is due to a type 3 hypersensitivity reaction (antigen-antibody complex).
  • Option 2: In fungal corneal ulcers, the hypopyon is not sterile. The fungi can penetrate into the anterior chamber without perforation.
  • Option 3: A sterile, immune ring (yellow line of demarcation), as well as multiple, small satellite lesions, may be present.



Reference: Parsons' Diseases of the Eye, 23rd edition, Page no 175.

questions.text: A trauma surgeon is assessing a patient brought in after a road traffic accident. The patient opens their eyes in response to painful stimuli, utters inappropriate words, and withdraws their limbs from pain. According to the Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS), what is the patient's score, broken down by Eye, Verbal, and Motor responses?
questions.solution:
The Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) score is used as an objective clinical measure of the severity of brain injury.
In the given scenario - the patient opens their eyes in response to pain(E2), utters inappropriate words(V3), and withdraws their limbs from pain(M4)



Reference: Harrison’s Principals of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page No 2218.

questions.text: An illustration of an injection near the medial canthus is shown. What steps are involved?
questions.solution:
The given image shows anterior ethmoidal nerve blockage procedure.

The anterior ethmoidal nerve supplies sensations to the roof of the nasal cavity. It's a branch of the nasociliary nerve which is a branch of the ophthalmic nerve (V1). This procedure is used in endonasal surgery. The procedure can also be carried during the treatment of nasal fractures.

Reference : P L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck surgery , 7th Edition- page 154

questions.text: A nutritionist is counseling a new mother on the benefits of breastfeeding. They are discussing the composition of breast milk and the essential nutrients it provides for the infant's development. Which specific fatty acid, abundant in breast milk, plays a crucial role in the baby's brain development and cognitive function?
questions.solution:
• Docosahexaenoic acid (DHA) is an omega-3 fatty acid that is abundant in breast milk and plays a crucial role in an infant’s brain development, cognitive function, and visual acuity.
  • DHA is essential for the growth and maturation of the brain and retina, particularly during the first 6 months to two years of life when rapid neural development occurs

Reference- Nelson Essentials Of Pediatrics Edition 21 st Page No 307

questions.text: A pharmacologist is reviewing the effects of muscarinic antagonists, drugs that block the action of acetylcholine at muscarinic receptors. Which of the following physiological responses is NOT a typical effect of muscarinic antagonists?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Contract radial muscles of iris 
 
  • Muscarinic antagonists, also known as anticholinergic drugs, block the action of acetylcholine at muscarinic receptors.
  • The general effects of muscarinic antagonists include (A) Decrease in secretion (B)Relaxation of smooth muscle (C)Dilation of the pupils.
  • Muscarinic antagonists typically decrease gastric secretions (option 1) and decrease respiratory secretions (option 2).
  • However, muscarinic antagonists do not contract the radial muscles of the iris (option 3). Instead, they block the action of acetylcholine on circular muscle, causing passive mydriasis and are called cycloplegics.
  • Muscarinic antagonists can also have an effect on AV conduction, as they can block the parasympathetic influence on the AV node, which may facilitate in AV conduction (option 4).
[Extra Edge]: Muscarinic Agonist Vs Antagonist



Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 112.

questions.text: A respiratory therapist is setting up oxygen therapy for a patient with hypoxemia. They are using a standard oxygen delivery system without a venturi mask. What is the maximum flow rate of oxygen that can be delivered using conventional oxygen therapy equipment?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 3. 15 l/min

Conventional oxygen therapy includes nasal cannulas, simple face masks, and non-rebreather masks. The maximum flow rate depends on the type of device used.
15 L/min is the maximum flow rate for non-rebreather masks, which provide the highest FiO without requiring advanced oxygenation techniques like Venturi masks or high-flow nasal cannula (HFNC).Beyond 15 L/min, HFNC or mechanical ventilation is typically required for better oxygenation and humidification.



Reference: Morgan and Mikhail's Clinical Anesthesiology, 5th edition, Page no 1282-1285.

questions.text: A male was brought with the following injury in a gunshot incident. What is the possible range from which the weapon inflicted injury?
questions.solution:
• Based on the stellate-shaped wound observed in the scenario, it appears to be a contact shot entrance wound.
  • When the barrel of a gun is placed in contact with the skin over the skull, firing the weapon results in gases ejected below the skin and an outward rupture that can create a roughly star-shaped injury in the skin
  • Because of the high-energy impact, a contact shot entry wound on the skull usually displays a stellate shape.
  • Entry wounds and exit wounds are the two basic forms of firearm wounds. The wound through which the bullet or pellets enter the body is known as the wound of entrance, and the wound through which the bullet leaves the body is known as the wound of exit.
Reference: Textbook of forensic medicine and toxicology 2nd edition page nos 280 and 283.

questions.text: A neurologist is evaluating a patient presenting with seizures and focal neurological deficits. Imaging studies reveal cystic lesions within the brain parenchyma. Which parasitic infection is the most likely cause of neurocysticercosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 2: Cysticercus cellulosae

C.Cellulose causes neurocysticercosis. It is the most common CNS parasitic infection and the most common cause of adult-onset epilepsy.

Other options
C. Bovis causes intestinal cysticercosis.
Hydatid cyst of the brain, also known as neuro hydatidosis is a condition caused by E. granuloses.

Reference: Paniker's Textbook of Medical Parasitology, 8th edition, Page no 126.

questions.text: A psychiatrist is evaluating a patient with Wernicke-Korsakoff syndrome, a neurological disorder often associated with chronic alcohol abuse and thiamine deficiency. Which brain region is typically NOT significantly affected in Wernicke-Korsakoff psychosis?
questions.solution:
• The correct option is 4. Hippocampus.
  • Wernicke's- Korsakoff psychosis is a neurological disorder caused by a deficiency of thiamine (vitamin B1) in the brain especially in chronic alcoholics. The disorder is characterized by a range of symptoms, including confusion, ophthalmoplegia and ataxia(Wernicke's encephalopathy) and memory loss/confabulation(Korsakoff's psychosis)
  • Other three options (1. Mamillary body, 2. Thalamus, and 3. Periventricular Grey matter) are all areas of the brain that are affected by Wernicke's Korsakoff psychosis.
  • Mamillary bodies (option 1) – One of the most affected areas, leading to memory impairment.
  • Thalamus (option 2) – Especially the dorsomedial nucleus, contributing to memory deficits.                         
  • Periventricular grey matter (option 3) – Often damaged, affecting autonomic and cognitive functions
  • The hippocampus (option 4) is not a primary site of damage in Wernicke-Korsakoff syndrome. While the hippocampus plays a crucial role in memory formation, WKS primarily affects the diencephalic structures (mamillary bodies and thalamus), rather than the hippocampus.
Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 3376.

questions.text: A geneticist is explaining the importance of CpG islands, regions of DNA with a high frequency of cytosine-guanine dinucleotides. What is the primary significance of CG islands in the context of gene regulation?
questions.solution:
• CpG islands are regions of DNA with a high frequency of cytosine-guanine (CG) dinucleotides, typically found in promoter regions of genes.
  • These regions are crucial for gene regulation, primarily through DNA methylation.
  • Methylation of CpG islands (addition of methyl groups to cytosine residues) leads to gene silencing by preventing transcription factor binding. 
  • Hypomethylation (low methylation) is associated with active gene transcription. 
  • Abnormal hypermethylation can lead to tumor suppressor gene silencing, contributing to cancer. 
Reference: Lippincott' Illustrated Reviews, 5th edition, Page no 460.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man presents with intensely itchy blisters arising on seemingly normal skin, accompanied by hives. Which investigation would be most helpful in confirming the suspected diagnosis of bullous pemphigoid?
questions.solution:
The correct answer is direct immunofluorescence.

Direct immunofluorescence of perilesional skin is the most specific and confirmatory test for bullous pemphigoid. Bullous pemphigoid is an autoimmune blistering disorder that typically affects the elderly. It presents with intensely itchy, tense blisters on normal or erythematous skin, often preceded by urticarial lesions.

Direct immunofluorescence is the gold standard for diagnosing bullous pemphigoid. A perilesional skin biopsy shows linear deposition of IgG and C3 along the basement membrane zone, confirming the presence of autoantibodies against hemidesmosomal proteins BP180 and BP230 in the dermoepidermal junction.

Other options

  • Option 2 - Indirect immunofluorescence detects circulating autoantibodies in serum but is less specific than direct immunofluorescence.
  • Option 3- Histopathology can show subepidermal blistering with eosinophilic infiltration but does not confirm autoantibody involvement.
  • Option 4- Cytopathology is used for detecting acantholytic cells in conditions like pemphigus vulgaris but is not helpful in bullous pemphigoid.



Reference- Rook's Textbook of Dermatology, 9th edition, Page number 50.8

questions.text: A critical care physician is evaluating several patients presenting with different types of shock: hypovolemic, cardiogenic, septic, and anaphylactic. Despite the different underlying causes, which physiological finding is common to all forms of shock?
questions.solution:
Shock is defined as a systemic condition marked by inadequate tissue perfusion, which fails to support normal cellular respiration which in turn leads to metabolic/lactic acidosis and later organ failure. Hence, reduced tissue perfusion i.e.  option 3 is common to all forms of shock

Other options

Option (1) Increased peripheral resistance – Seen in hypovolemic and cardiogenic shock due to compensatory vasoconstriction but decreased in septic and anaphylactic shock due to systemic vasodilation.

Option (2) Decreased respiratory rate – Shock often leads to tachypnea (increased respiratory rate) as a compensatory mechanism for metabolic acidosis and hypoxia.

Option (4) Cold clammy skin – Present in hypovolemic and cardiogenic shock due to vasoconstriction but absent in septic and anaphylactic shock, where peripheral vasodilation causes warm, flushed skin.



Reference- Guyton and Hall Textbook of Medical Physiology, Edition 13, pg no 234

questions.text: Researchers are using "naked mice" (mice lacking mature T cells) for a xenotransplantation study. The absence of which immune component makes these mice suitable for studying graft rejection without the usual immune response?
questions.solution:
Nude mice are not able to reject xenograft due to absence of T cell. A xenograft is a tissue graft or organ transplant form a donor of a different species.
Nude mice lack body hair hence the name. They lack a thymus and thus cannot generate mature T-lymphocytes. The absence of T-lymphocytes makes them unable to mount adaptive immune responses requiring helper T-cells and cytotoxic T-cells. The absence of functioning T-cells also prevents the rejection of allografts and xenografts.

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathology,10th edition, page no 217.

questions.text: A boy presents with a dog bite and complains of blood oozing from the wound. Which of the following should be administered?
questions.solution:
Dog bite with blood oozing from the wound should be treated as a category III wound and treated with both Rabies immunoglobulin and vaccine.



Reference - https://ncdc.mohfw.gov.in/wp-content/uploads/2024/02/Guidelines-for-Rabies-Prophylaxis.pdf

questions.text: A patient arrives at the emergency department experiencing acute, life-threatening cardiogenic pulmonary edema. The medical team initiates immediate treatment to stabilize the patient. Which of the following interventions is NOT typically part of the initial management of this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: Digoxin


Acute cardiogenic pulmonary edema is a medical emergency caused by left ventricular failure, leading to fluid accumulation in the lungs. Immediate treatment focuses on reducing pulmonary congestion, improving oxygenation, and stabilizing hemodynamics.

Management includes

  • Furosemide (option 3) – A loop diuretic that reduces preload by promoting diuresis, helping to relieve pulmonary congestion.
  • Morphine (option 2) – Used in some cases to reduce anxiety, preload, and sympathetic response (though its use has declined due to potential respiratory depression).
  • Positive Pressure Ventilation (option 4) – Non-invasive ventilation (e.g., CPAP or BiPAP) improves oxygenation and reduces cardiac workload.

Digoxin is NOT part of the initial emergency management of acute cardiogenic pulmonary edema because It works slowly and is mainly used for chronic heart failure or atrial fibrillation. It does not provide immediate relief for pulmonary congestion or respiratory distress.

Management of Acute Cardiogenic Pulmonary Edema:



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 1942, 1943, 1950.

questions.text: A medical student is studying muscle fiber orientation. Which of the following muscles does NOT have parallel-oriented fibers?
questions.solution:
Tibialis anterior is a multipinnate muscle with both parallel and obliquely oriented fibers. 
Sartorius, Rectus abdominis and sternohyoid - all have parallel oriented fibres. 

Reference : Gray's Anatomy: The Anatomical Basis of Clinical Practice,41st Edition - page no.113

questions.text: A young athlete experiences severe muscle cramps and fatigue during strenuous exercise. Biochemical analysis reveals an accumulation of glycogen in his muscle tissue. Which enzyme is most likely deficient?
questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette points towards McArdle's disease, also known as type V glycogen disease.
It is an autosomal recessive disorder which occurs due to deficiency of myophosphorylase- muscle glycogen phosphorylase. This results in inability of muscles to utilise glycogen leading to muscle cramps, exercise intolerance and accumulation of glycogen in muscles. 

Option 1- Glycogen phosphorylase deficiency results in Hers disease-type VI glycogen storage disease.
Option 3- Deficiency of glucose-6-phosphatase results in Von Gierke Disease- Type I glycogen storage disease.
Option 4- Glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase deficiency results in hemolytic anemia with characteristic bite cells on peripheral smear. 

Reference: Harper’s Illustrated Biochemistry, 31st edition, Page no 175.

questions.text: A sleep researcher is analyzing a hypnogram, a graphical representation of sleep stages over time. The hypnogram shows distinct patterns of brainwave activity, muscle tone, and eye movements. Which stage of sleep is represented by the pink boxes in the given hypnogram?
questions.solution:
Pink box is marked by
1. Low muscle tone (EMG - flat line)
2. Rapid eye movements (EOG shows movement)
3. EEG resembling wakefulness.

This suggest REM phase of sleep



Reference- Ganong’s Review of Medical Physiology Edition 26 th Page no 272

choices.text: NOAC ( New oral Anticoagulants) are used in atrial fibrillation and mitral stenosis
Patients with ischemic stroke due to Atrial Fibrilation can be started on anticoagulation

questions.text: Consider the following statements in AF patients:
questions.solution:
Correct option(2) Statements 2, 3 are correct

Novel Oral Anticoagulants (NOACs), also referred to as direct oral anticoagulants, comprise a new category of anticoagulants that includes the oral thrombin inhibitor dabigatran and oral factor Xa inhibitors such as rivaroxaban, apixaban, and edoxaban. These medications are user-friendly, provide reliable anticoagulation, and do not necessitate dosage adjustments based on blood testing. Compared to warfarin, they have a lower risk of intracranial hemorrhage and serve as alternatives for patients with atrial fibrillation.
 
  • Statement 1: NOACs are not recommended for treating moderate to severe mitral stenosis (MS) due to limited clinical evidence regarding their efficacy and safety in this condition. Warfarin is the preferred anticoagulant for patients with mitral stenosis and mechanical prosthetic valves. Hence, statement 1 is false.
  • Statement 2: NOACs are contraindicated in individuals with prosthetic mechanical heart valves because of insufficient evidence. Warfarin is given in such cases. Hence, statement 2 is true.
  • Statement 3: For patients experiencing ischemic stroke due to atrial fibrillation, anticoagulation with either warfarin or NOACs is recommended. In cases of small or moderate-sized infarcts without intracranial bleeding, warfarin can be initiated shortly (after 24 hours) following admission, as the risk of transitioning to hemorrhagic stroke is minimal. NOACs can be started after 48 hours due to their quicker anticoagulant effects. Hence, statement 3 is also true. 
  • Statement 4: Beta blockers and CCBs are first line drugs used to achieve rate control in AF. Hence, statement 4 is incorrect. 
Therefore - only statement 2,3 are correct - which is option 2. 

Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page no 935, 1905-1907.

questions.text: A male patient is found to have anti-HBe antibody positivity, HBs Ag antigen positivity, and HBe Ag antigen negativity. While SGOT and SGPT are raised to 6 times the upper limit of normal value, HBV DNA copies are detected to be 100,000/ml. What plausible diagnosis is there?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 2: HBV precore mutant
 
  • The patient has anti-HBe antibody positivity, HBsAg positivity, and HBeAg negativity. These serological markers suggest a transition from the immune tolerant phase to the immune clearance phase of chronic HBV infection. The presence of raised SGOT and SGPT levels indicates liver inflammation.
  • The key feature in this case is the detection of HBV DNA copies at 100,000/ml. A precore mutant HBV infection is characterized by the absence of HBeAg production due to a mutation in the precore region of the HBV genome. This leads to a decrease or absence of HBeAg in the serum, despite ongoing viral replication.
  • Therefore, the most likely diagnosis in this case is HBV precore mutant infection.




Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2576.

questions.text: An environmental engineer is explaining the wastewater treatment process in an oxidation pond. What is the dominant microbial process during the day and night cycles in a typical oxidation pond?
questions.solution:
Oxidation ponds (also known as stabilization ponds or lagoons) are used in sewage and industrial waste treatment. They are shallow, open pools that typically measure around 1-1.5 meters in depth, and they rely on the interaction of algae, saprophytic bacteria, and sunlight to treat waste.

Process:
The organic matter in the sewage or waste is broken down by bacteria, producing carbon dioxide, ammonia, and water. The algae in the pond use these products for growth through photosynthesis, with the help of sunlight, which in turn helps maintain the oxygen balance in the system.

During the day, when sunlight is available, aerobic conditions predominate, as the algae produce oxygen for the bacteria to break down organic matter. This oxygen sustains aerobic bacteria in the breakdown process.

At night, when photosynthesis ceases, the oxygen levels drop, and anaerobic conditions can develop, especially in the deeper layers of the pond. The bottom layers are more likely to remain anaerobic during nighttime hours.

Effluent Use:
The effluent from oxidation ponds can be used for land irrigation or forwarded for further treatment depending on the quality of the treated water.

This cyclical aerobic and anaerobic process helps in the natural breakdown of waste, providing a cost-effective method of sewage treatment, especially in areas with sufficient land and sunlight.


Reference - https://biologyreader.com/oxidation-pond.html

questions.text: A patient presents to a vascular surgeon complaining of intermittent claudication, a cramping pain in his calf muscles that occurs predictably after walking a specific distance. The pain subsides with rest and then recurs after walking the same distance again. Using Boyd's grading system for peripheral artery disease (PAD), which classifies the severity of claudication based on the distance walked before pain onset, what grade does this patient's claudication correspond to?
questions.solution:
• The patient's pain subsides with rest, indicating a classification of Grade III according to Boyd's classification of claudication.
  • Grade III is characterized by intermittent claudication, where the patient experiences muscle pain, cramping (typically in the calves) on walking and the pain typically resolves with rest.

Boyd's classification of claudication:



Reference  https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC4232437/#:~:text=Table%202.%20Rutherford%20classification%20for%20chronic%20limb%20ischemia

choices.text: Congested vessels cannot be moved with cotton bud

questions.text: An ophthalmologist is differentiating between episcleritis and scleritis, two inflammatory conditions affecting the outer layers of the eye. Which clinical sign is more suggestive of episcleritis rather than scleritis?
questions.solution:
Correct option is 4: Blanching of vessels with 10% phenylephrine.
 
  • Episcleritis and scleritis are both inflammatory conditions that affect the outer layers of the eye.
  • One characteristic that suggests episcleritis rather than scleritis is the ability of the congested vessels to blanch or fade upon instillation of a vasoconstrictor, such as 10% phenylephrine eye drops.
  • In episcleritis, the blood vessels are superficial and located in the episcleral layer, allowing them to blanch when vasoconstrictors are applied.
  • In contrast, scleritis involves deeper layers of the sclera, and the blood vessels are less likely to blanch with vasoconstrictors.




Reference: Ophthalmology by Yanoff and Duker, 5th edition, Page no 212, 213.
