questions.text: A 3-year-old boy is brought to the ophthalmology clinic by his parents, who are concerned about his increasing clumsiness and a noticeable white pupillary reflex (leukocoria) in his left eye. On examination, the ophthalmologist observes a cauliflower-like growth protruding from the retina and confirms the absence of a red reflex. A biopsy of the growth reveals characteristic Flexner-Wintersteiner rosettes under the microscope. Which gene is most commonly implicated in the development of this condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical history(leucocoria/cauliflower like mass from retina) and histological findings(Flexner-Wintersteiner rosettes) suggest retinoblastoma. Its a malignancy caused by a mutation in the Rb gene on chromosome 13q14.

Retinoblastoma is the most common intraocular cancer in children, and leukocoria (white pupillary reflex) is the most frequent presenting symptom. Other signs include strabismus (usually convergent) and, less commonly, nystagmus and defective vision. On histology its a Small round blue cell tumor with Flexner-Wintersteiner rosettes and stains positive for synaptophysin and chromogranin. 



Reference - Retinoblastoma GeneReviews (https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK1452/

questions.text: A gynecologist is reviewing patient demographics and risk factors for vulvar cancer. In which age group is vulvar cancer most commonly diagnosed?
questions.solution:
The incidence of vulvar cancer increases with age, and it is most commonly diagnosed in women over the age of 60.Vulvar cancer is most common in postmenopausal women, with the peak incidence occurring in the 6th to 8th decades of life.However, HPV-associated vulvar cancers can occur in younger women (30–50 years), but these are less common compared to the overall incidence in older age groups.

Reference: Shaw's Textbook of Gynaecology, 17th edition Page no 475-477.

questions.text: A patient presents with a constellation of symptoms including mononeuritis multiplex (affecting multiple individual nerves), polymyalgia rheumatica (muscle pain and stiffness), jaw claudication (pain with chewing), persistent headaches. What is the most appropriate initial treatment for this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct option is 1: Prednisolone.

The patient is presenting with symptoms of giant cell arteritis (GCA), which is an inflammatory disease of the arteries. 

GCA can cause a number of symptoms, including:
  • Headache
  • Jaw claudication (pain in the jaw when chewing)
  • Polymyalgia rheumatica (pain and stiffness in the shoulders and hips)
  • Mononeuritis multiplex (inflammation of multiple nerves)
  • Amarausis fugax 
The initial course of treatment for GCA is high-dose prednisolone. It is especially important to start prednisolone as soon as GCA is suspected, due to the risk of vision loss by ophthalmic artery involvement.

Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page no 2811, 2812.

questions.text: A respiratory physiologist is explaining the neural control of breathing to students. They are discussing the different groups of neurons within the brainstem that are involved in generating and regulating respiratory rhythm. Where is the primary respiratory rhythm generator located, responsible for the basic pattern of inspiration and expiration?
questions.solution:
Prebotzinger complex - acts as the pacemaker of respiration and primary rhythm generator.

 Pre-Botzinger complex (PBC) is a specialised area and is located in the rostral part of the VRG( Ventral respiratory group) and is thhe centre of respiratory rhythm generation.

Other options:

  1. Dorsal respiratory group (DRG): Primarily involved in the control of inspiration, it receives input from chemoreceptors and sends signals to the diaphragm and external intercostal muscles but does not generate the primary rhythm.
  2. Ventral respiratory neurons: Involved in both inspiration and expiration, especially during more forceful breathing, but not the primary rhythm generator.
  3. Pneumotaxic center: Located in the pons, it modulates the rate and depth of breathing but does not generate the primary rhythm.

Reference- Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology Edition 26 th Page no 646

choices.text: Surgical treatment with functional endoscopic sinus surgery should be carried out
Beta-2 transferrin protein detection by electrophoresis is a sensitive and specific test for detecting CSF rhinorrhea.
High-resolution computerized tomography (HRCT) is the investigation of choice
Fracture of the cribriform plate of the ethmoid is the most common cause

questions.text: A 30-year-old female is brought to the emergency department following a road traffic accident. She presents with a clear, watery nasal discharge tinged with blood. Which of the following statements regarding the condition is FALSE?
questions.solution:
• The given clinical scenario is suggestive of CSF rhinorrhea( clear, watery nasal discharge post trauma).
  • It refers to the leakage of cerebrospinal fluid into the nose. It can occur as clear fluid or be mixed with blood, particularly in cases of acute head injuries.
  • Fracture of the cribriform plate of the ethmoid is the most common cause of this. Hence, option 4 is correct statement
  • Beta-2 transferrin protein detection by electrophoresis is a sensitive and specific test for detecting CSF rhinorrhea. Hence, option 2 is correct statement
  • High-resolution computerized tomography (HRCT) is the investigation of choice for localizing, the site of the leak. Hence, option 3 is correct statement
  • Surgical treatment with functional endoscopic sinus surgery should not be done as it increases chances of meningitis - hence, option 1 is false and the answer.

Ref- P L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and neck surgery - 8th Edition • Page nos: 191-193

questions.text:
Q2. Which maneuver is being performed?


1. Jaw thrust
2. Head tilt, chin lift
3. In-line spine stabilization
4. Cardiopulmonary resuscitation
questions.solution:
The maneuver performed in the given image is that of a head-tilt chin-lift.

  • It is an important technique in emergency airway management to open up the airway.
  • Before performing this maneuver, it is essential to rule out cervical spine injury.


Reference: Miller's Anesthesia, 9th Edition, Page No 2157.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presents to the gynecology clinic with a complaint of heavy menstrual bleeding (menorrhagia) that has persisted for the past six months. A physical examination and pelvic ultrasound are performed, and both reveal no obvious abnormalities. What is the most appropriate next step in the evaluation of this patient's abnormal uterine bleeding, given the normal findings on initial assessment?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 1. Endometrial sampling

  • Since in a peri-menopausal women the clinical examination and ultrasound has not revealed any abnormalities, we should go for a Endometrial sampling to asses for any abnormalities of endometrium.
  • It is used to rule out malignancy and also to find out any benign/pre-malignant changes in the endometrium.

Management protocol for AUB is summarised below:




 


Reference: Shaw's Textbook of Gynaecology, 17th edition, Page no 134, 135.
DC Dutta's Textbook of Gynecology, 8th edition, Page no 163.

questions.text: What kind of breast examination technique is done if the physician palpated with the tips of all fingers save the thumb starting at 2 o'clock posterior palpated at three locations on line joining periphery to nipple. Then moved directly to 3 o'clock and returned centripetally while palpating at 3 locations on the line connecting periphery and nipple?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Dial of Clock method
 
  • The described method of breast examination is known as "Dial of Clock" method.
  • In dial of clock method, palpation is performed in segmental manner until entire breast is examined with “pads of middle three fingers” (index, middle, and ring) with hand held in slightly bowed position.
  • The examination starts at a specific clock position, such as 2 o'clock, and palpates at different points along a line from the periphery to the nipple.
  • The physician then moves to the next clock position, such as 3 o'clock, and repeats the process, covering the entire breast in a systematic manner.
  • This approach ensures a thorough examination of all breast tissue, especially targeting areas where abnormalities might be present



Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 916.

questions.text: A cytogeneticist is analyzing a patient's karyotype and observes a mixture of cells with different chromosome numbers within the same individual. Which of the following chromosomal abnormalities arises from a mitotic error ?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 4): Mosaicism
 
  • Aneuploidy refers to an abnormal number of chromosomes in a cell.
  • Errors during cell division can lead to aneuploidy.
  • Mosaicism occurs when an individual has two or more genetically different cell populations within their body due to a mitotic error that happens after fertilization. This leads to a mixture of normal and abnormal cells, each with different chromosome numbers. Mosaicism results from postzygotic mitotic nondisjunction.

Other options

  • Uniparental disomy occurs when both copies of a chromosome come from one parent due to a meiotic error, not a mitotic error.
  • Monosomy is the loss of a chromosome in all cells, usually due to meiotic nondisjunction rather than a mitotic error.
  • Trisomy is the presence of an extra chromosome in all cells, typically resulting from a meiotic nondisjunction event rather than mosaicis

[Extra Edge]: Chromosomal Abnormality




Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 165.

questions.text: A researcher is preparing to visualize chromosomes using a light microscope. What is the approximate resolution limit of a standard light microscope, representing the smallest discernible detail that can be observed when viewing chromosomes?
questions.solution:
The correct answer is 5 Mb.

  • The resolution limit of a standard light microscope is approximately 200 nanometers. This allows visualization of chromosomes at the metaphase stage when they are highly condensed, but not at the molecular level of DNA sequences.
  • The smallest detectable segment of DNA under a light microscope is typically around 5 megabases.
  • Higher-resolution techniques like fluorescence in situ hybridization or super-resolution microscopy are required to observe smaller DNA fragments.

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathology, 10th edition, Page no 164.

questions.text: An oncologist is preparing a chemotherapy regimen for a patient with a brain tumor. They are considering using temozolomide. To which class of antineoplastic agents does temozolomide belong?
questions.solution:
Temozolomide belongs to the class of alkylating agents.

Temozolomide is an oral chemotherapy drug that works by adding alkyl groups to the DNA, which interferes with the DNA's ability to replicate and repair itself, ultimately leading to cancer cell death. This mechanism places it within the alkylating agent category.

Here’s why the other options are not correct:

  • Antimetabolites: These drugs interfere with DNA and RNA synthesis by mimicking the building blocks of DNA or RNA, but temozolomide does not work in this way.
  • Antitumor antibodies: These are typically monoclonal antibodies that target specific cancer cell markers, and temozolomide is not an antibody.
  • Enzymes: Enzyme-based therapies typically involve using or inhibiting specific enzymes to interfere with cancer cell function, which does not describe temozolomide's mechanism.

So, the correct answer is 3. Alkylating agent.


Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 920.

questions.text: A 15-year-old boy who has been taking amoxicillin for a sore throat for the past week now presents with multiple episodes of watery diarrhea, fever, and an elevated white blood cell count. Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment for this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
The correct answer is option 2 - Oral fidaxomicin.

The patient's symptoms of watery diarrhea, fever, and elevated white blood cell count after a course of amoxicillin suggest Clostridioides difficile infection Clostridium difficile infection causing pseudomembranous enterocolitis. . Antibiotic use disrupts normal gut flora, allowing C. difficile to overgrow and produce toxins, leading to diarrhea and colitis.

First-line treatment for C. difficile infection includes oral fidaxomicin due to its high efficacy and lower recurrence rates. Oral vancomycin is also a first-line option, especially when fidaxomicin is unavailable. Metronidazole is no longer preferred but may be used for mild cases if other options are unavailable.

Other options

  • Option 1 - Intravenous vancomycin is ineffective for C. difficile because it does not reach the colon in sufficient concentrations.
  • Option 3- Intravenous ceftriaxone is a broad-spectrum antibiotic that can worsen C. difficile infection by further disrupting gut flora.
  • Option 4- Oral clindamycin is a high-risk antibiotic for C. difficile and would worsen the condition rather than treat it.

Reference: Harrison’s Principals of Internal Medicine, 20st Edition, Page No: 965, 966.

questions.text: An anesthesiologist observes slowing of the EEG during the induction phase of general anesthesia. Which of the following factors is most likely responsible for this observation?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 4. Hypothermia
 
  • EEG slowing/suppression during induction of anesthesia is due to Hypothermia.
  • Profound hypothermia leads to completely electrically silent EEG. 
  • During anesthesia induction, the brain's activity slows down, which is reflected in the EEG as a decrease in frequency and amplitude. This slowing of EEG activity is a normal response to anesthesia and is caused by the action of anesthetics on the brain. There are slower EEG waveforms, particularly in the theta and delta ranges, as brain activity decreases.
  • Hypothermia can lead to a decrease in brain activity, which is reflected in the EEG as slowing of the frequency and amplitude.
  • Ketamine and nitrous oxide are also commonly used anesthetics, but they do not typically cause EEG slowing during induction. Early hypoxia, or a decrease in oxygen supply to the brain, can cause EEG changes, but it is not a common cause of EEG slowing during anesthesia induction.
Reference: Miller's Anesthesia, 9th edition, Page no 1275.

questions.text: During a normal laboratory check, a patient's HBsAg status is discovered to be positive. Other hepatitis serological testing are unremarkable. His liver enzymes are within the normal range, and he exhibits no clinical symptoms. Which of the following options most accurately sums up his diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The correct answer is option 1 - inactive HBV carrier.

A patient with a positive HBsAg, normal liver enzymes, no symptoms, and unremarkable other hepatitis serological markers is most consistent with an inactive HBV carrier state.

HBsAg positivity indicates current HBV infection, either acute or chronic. Normal liver enzymes suggest no active liver inflammation. The absence of symptoms supports a chronic carrier state rather than acute hepatitis. Unremarkable other hepatitis markers likely indicate low or undetectable HBV DNA, suggesting low viral replication.

Other options

  • Acute hepatitis B would present with elevated liver enzymes, HBsAg positivity, HBc IgM positivity, and possible symptoms such as jaundice or fatigue.
  • Active Chronic hepatitis B would have HBsAg positivity for more than six months, IgG anti-HBc, elevated liver enzymes, and detectable HBV DNA along with HbeAg indicating ongoing viral replication.

Serological markers of Hepatitis B:




Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2576-2578.

questions.text: A forensic pathologist is conducting a postmortem examination. They are analyzing various body fluids and tissues for the presence of substances that could contribute to the cause of death. Which of the following substances can be seen in the body after death, even if it wasn't actually ingested by the person- making it detectable during postmortem toxicology analysis?
questions.solution:
After death, the body undergoes various biological processes, including putrefaction. During putrefaction, bacteria present in the gastrointestinal tract and other tissues can ferment carbohydrates, leading to the production of alcohol.

Therefore, Alcohol can normally be detected in visceral organs, even if it was not consumed before death.

Ref- Essentials of Forensic Medicine and Toxicology 35th edition Page 97

questions.text: A young woman presents to a reproductive endocrinologist with primary amenorrhea, the absence of menstruation by age 15. Physical examination reveals a lack of axillary hair and normal breast development. Pelvic examination shows clitoromegaly (enlarged clitoris) and a normally formed vagina. Ultrasound reveals the presence of gonads in the inguinal region. Based on these findings, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Partial androgen insensitivity syndrome
Findings of clitoromegaly with no axillary hairs and typical breast development are suggestive of partial AIS.
 

  • Partial androgen insensitivity syndrome is a condition caused by mutations in the androgen receptor (AR) gene, leading to partial resistance to androgens. This results in a spectrum of phenotypic presentations depending on the degree of receptor dysfunction.

    The key features in this patient that suggest PAIS include:

  • Primary amenorrhea due to the absence of a functional uterus and ovaries.
  • Normal breast development due to estrogen production from aromatization of androgens.
  • Lack of axillary hair due to androgen insensitivity.
  • Clitoromegaly suggesting partial responsiveness to androgens.
  • Gonads in the inguinal region on ultrasound, which are testes rather than ovaries.




Reference: Shaw's Textbook of Gynaecology,17th edition, Page no 109, 113.

questions.text: A hematologist is reviewing lab results that show an abnormal Ham test (acidified serum lysis test). This test is used to diagnose paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria (PNH). Which of the following underlying defects is most likely associated with a positive Ham test?
questions.solution:
• The correct answer is option 1 - defective GPI anchor protein.
  • The Ham test (acidified serum lysis test) is used to diagnose paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria, a disorder caused by a defect in the GPI (glycosylphosphatidylinositol) anchor protein.
  • PNH is caused by a mutation in the PIGA gene, leading to a deficiency of GPI-anchored proteins, particularly CD55 (decay-accelerating factor) and CD59 (membrane inhibitor of reactive lysis). These proteins normally protect red blood cells from complement-mediated lysis. Their absence makes red blood cells highly sensitive to complement activation, especially in acidic conditions (used in ham test), leading to intravascular hemolysis.

Other options

  • A complement defect does not cause PNH, as the disease results from increased complement sensitivity rather than a primary complement system abnormality.
  • A spectrin defect is associated with hereditary spherocytosis, not PNH.
  • A mannose-binding residue defect is related to immune deficiencies rather than hemolytic anemia.

The Ham test has largely been replaced by flow cytometry to detect CD55 and CD59 deficiency, but it historically helped diagnose PNH, which is caused by a defective GPI anchor protein.

Reference-: Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease Edition 10 th Page no 64

questions.text: A 34-year-old male presented with a painless mass in the right inguinal region. On examination, there is a cough impulse on the index finger and the swelling reaches down to the scrotum and is reduced completely by pressing it through the deep inguinal ring with a gurgling sound. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The patient presents with a painless inguinal mass that:

  • Has a cough impulse (indicating a reducible hernia).
  • Extends down to the scrotum (suggesting passage through the inguinal canal).
  • Is completely reducible by pressing through the deep inguinal ring with a gurgling sound (suggesting bowel content within the hernia sac).

These features are characteristic of an indirect inguinal hernia.

Reference: Bailey and loves short practice of surgery 27th edition page no 1029

questions.text: A housemaid presents with pain and swelling anterior to her knee. The physician diagnoses inflammation of the bursa located just below the patella. What is another name for this condition?
questions.solution:
Inflammation of the bursa just below knee is infrapatellar bursitis. Infrapatellar bursitis is also known as Clergyman's knee/Parson's knee. 

Other options
  • Housemaid's knee- Prepatellar bursitis
  • Weaver's bottom- ischial bursitis
  • Taylor's knee- doesn't exist. Rather taylor's muscle is another name for Sartorius whereas taylor's brace is used for spine. 

Reference-: Essential Orthopaedics by Maheshwari Edition 7th Page no 301

questions.text: A neuroanatomist is tracing the fiber tracts within the cerebellum. The image shows the dentate nucleus, the largest and most lateral of the cerebellar deep nuclei. To which brainstem nucleus do fibers originating from the dentate nucleus primarily project?
questions.solution:
Fibers originating from the dentate nucleus primarily project to the red nucleus in the brainstem, specifically via the dentatorubrothalamic pathway, which then relays signals to the thalamus to reach the cerebral cortex; this pathway is crucial for motor control. 
Key points about the dentate nucleus projections:
  • Target in the brainstem: Red nucleus
  • Pathway: Dentatorubrothalamic pathway
  • Function: Fine motor control by modulating cortical activity through the thalamus 
  

Reference: Gray's Anatomy The Anatomical Basis Of Clinical Practice Edition 42 nd Page no 468,481

questions.text: A neurologist is evaluating a patient with oculomotor nerve (CN III) palsy. The patient exhibits several eye movement abnormalities. Which of the following findings is NOT typically associated with oculomotor nerve palsy?
questions.solution:
Correct Option: 1. Miosis.
  • Complete Oculomotor Palsy leads to Mydriasis, NOT Miosis.
  • Along with the levator palpebrae superioris (LPS) and pupillary sphincter, the oculomotor nerve innervates four extraocular muscles: the medial, superior & inferior rectus and inferior oblique. As a result, during palsy there is total ptosis (Option 2)
  • Nerve to IO carries along with it nerve fibres supplying Sphinter pupillae via Short ciliary nerves; so there is dilated pupil when the palsy is complete (mydriasis, not the miosis). This is due to Sphincter denervation.
  • The affected eye is also turned outward (laterally), typically downward (Option 3).
  • Oculomotor nerve is the efferent nerve of pupillary/ light reflex after relay in Edinger Westphal nucleus, so its palsy leads to impaired pupillary reflex (Option 4).

Reference: Ophthalmology by Yanoff and Duker, 5th edition, Page no 1228, 1229.

questions.text: A child came with the following finding. Which vitamin deficiency is responsible?
questions.solution:
The given image shows bowing of the legs or genu varum, which occurs due to rickets that results from the deficiency of vitamin D. Deficiency of vitamin D and calcium results in poor mineralization of bone, leading to rickets in children and osteomalacia in adults.




Fig: Metabolism Of Vitamin D

Other options
  • Vit C deficiency causes scurvy 
  • Vit A deficiency causes night blindness
  • Vit B3 deficiency causes pellagra 

Reference: Harrison’s Principals of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page No 2531.

questions.text: An embryologist is explaining the development of the urogenital system. Which of the following structures is NOT derived from the mesonephros, the embryonic kidney that functions during the early stages of fetal development?
questions.solution:
Among the given options, glomerulus is not derived from mesonephros. Rather, it is derived from the metanephric blastema and is mesodermal in origin. 

Epididymis and vas deferens in males are derived from duct of mesonephros ( Wolfian duct ) whereas the paroophoron is derived from mesonephric tubules in females,
 

Reference: Langman' Medical Embryology Edition 14 th page no 256,257

questions.text: A hematologist is evaluating a patient for suspected splenomegaly. Which of the following conditions is LEAST likely to cause an enlarged spleen?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Aplastic anemia
 
  • Aplastic Anemia is a condition in which there is complete absence of both intra and extramedullary hemopoiesis. Hence, there is no splenomegaly in this case.
  • Lymphoma and leukemia present with splenomegaly Due to splenic involvement by malignant cells. 
  • Hairy cell leukemia has bone marrow infiltration resulting in extramedullary hemopoiesis presenting as splenomegaly.
Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 659.

questions.text: Which of the following organism is transferred by the parasite shown below?
questions.solution:
The given image shows - trombiculid mite.

The trombiculid mite is the vector responsible for transmitting Orientia tsutsugamushi (option 1), the causative agent of scrub typhus, also known as chigger-borne typhus. Humans become infected when bitten by the mite‘s larvae, known as chiggers. The disease has an incubation period of 1 to 3 weeks.

Patients typically develop a distinctive eschar at the site of the mite bite, along with regional lymph node swelling (lymphadenopathy) and a maculopapular rash. Symptoms can include fever, headache, and conjunctival injection. In severe cases, complications such as meningoencephalitis, myocarditis, and pneumonia may occur.

The preferred treatment for scrub typhus is Doxycycline and Azithromycin together(new update).
 

Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page no 977

questions.text:
A patient presents to the outpatient clinic with a noticeable midline neck swelling that moves upward upon swallowing. The patient also exhibits exophthalmos (protruding eyeballs) and tachycardia (rapid heart rate). Which investigations are most appropriate to evaluate this patient's condition and confirm the diagnosis?

(i) Thyroid scan
(ii) FNAC
(iii) Thyroid function tests
(iv) USG neck
(v) Anti-thyroid antibodies
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) i, iii, iv, v

The given clinical history is suggestive of Grave’s disease. Antibodies Involved are TSH receptor antibodies.

Investigations

  • Thyroid function tests : Increase in TSH, T3, T4. 
  • USG Neck : Diffuse midline neck swelling. 
  • Anti - Thyroid Antibodies present.
FNAC is not done as it can precipitate Thyroid storm. 

Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 860.

questions.text: A psychiatrist is evaluating a patient with bipolar disorder and a history of suicidal ideation. They are considering different mood stabilizers for long-term treatment. Which of the following mood stabilizers has demonstrated anti-suicidal properties in clinical studies?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Lithium
 
  • Lithium is a mood stabilizer with anti-suicidal properties. It is the DOC in prophylaxis and treatment of BPD.
  • It acts by decreasing the levels of excitatory neurotransmitters like Glutamate and increases the activity of GABA. It also downregulates the NMDA receptors.
Some important values related to lithium



Valproate is given to rapid cyclers in BPD. Carbamazepine and Lamotrigine are also effective in BPD but none of them reduce the suicidal tendencies.

Reference: Goodman & Gilman’s the Pharmacological Basis of Therapeutics, 14th edition, Page No 378.

questions.text: A neuropsychologist is asking an individual  to touch their nose with their finger, then the examiner's finger, and repeat this quickly. On asking to do this - patient is unabe to perform this simple task. Which of the following explains this?
questions.solution:
The finger-to-nose test is a standard neurological examination used to assess cerebellar function. The inability to perform this test suggests dysmetria, a hallmark of cerebellar dysfunction. Dysmetria is the inability to properly control the range and force of movements, causing overshooting (hypermetria) or undershooting (hypometria) of the target

Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 3280, 3400.

questions.text: What is the most common drawback of the given device?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Drug deposited in the oropharynx
 
  • The given device is pMDI (Pressurised metered dose inhaler).
  • Most common drawback of pMDI is drug deposition in oropharynx.
  • Gas used is HFA (Hydroxyfluoro-alkaline gas which propels the drug out.
  • Another disadvantage is difficulty in coordinating press with inspiration.
  • Hence, cannot be used in small children without use of spacer. 
Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 9.

questions.text: A farmer notices his cattle exhibiting strange neurological symptoms, including blindness and erratic gait, and suspects mineral toxicity. Analysis of the forage reveals elevated levels of a particular element. Which element is the most likely culprit?
questions.solution:
Selenium toxicity (selenosis) in cattle can cause neurological symptoms, including blindness, ataxia (erratic gait), and behavioral abnormalities. Chronic selenium poisoning, often due to ingestion of selenium-rich forage or soils, leads to a condition known as alkali disease or blind staggers in livestock.

Reference: Acute selenium toxicity associated with a dietary supplement. Arch Intern Med. 2010 Feb 8;170(3):256-61. doi: 10.1001/archinternmed.2009.495. PMID: 20142570.

questions.text: A 24 years old patient with history of neck swelling on Right side of thyroid which moves with deglutition, invading into anterior strap muscle. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given histological images shows orphan Annie eye appearance suggestive of Papillary Carcinoma. 
Following histological features are suggestive of Papillary CA Thyroid:
  • Papillary architecture with fibrovascular cone
  • Coffee bean nuclei/ Orphan Annie eye nuclei
  • Nuclear pseudo inclusions
  • Psammoma bodies


Reference: Robbins & Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 10th edition, Page no 1088, 1089.

questions.text: Correctly match regarding the Eruption of permanent teeth
questions.solution:
1. Incisor - erupts at 7-8 years (option c)
2. Canine - erupts at 11-12 years (option d)
3. 1st molar - erupts at 6-7 years (option b)
4. 3rd molar - erupts at 17-25 years (option a)

questions.text: A female patient presents with metastatic adenocarcinoma in the liver. Immunohistochemical staining shows the tumor to be CK7 negative, CK20 positive, and CDX-1 positive. What is the most probable primary site of origin?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Colorectal ca
  • CDX-1 + IHC marker for metastatic liver adenocarcinoma means colorectal carcinoma is the possible answer.
  • Transcription factors unique to the gut require genes CDX-1 and 2 which control intestine phenotypic development, differentiation, and maintenance.
  • CK7 and CK 20 are used to identify organ of origin in carcinoma of unknown primary.  
  • Colorectal Adenocarcinoma is CK 7 negative.
Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 814.

questions.text:
A 28-year-old lady is being evaluated for multiple, subsequent miscarriages. An ultrasound suggests a mullerian abnormality.
What is the most effective technique to verify this?
questions.solution:
There is already suspicion of Mullerian anomaly on ultrasound.
So a diagnostic laproscopy and hysteroscopy can be done which will give view of both inside and outside contour of the uterus which can confirm the type of Mullerian anomaly.





Diagnosis of Mullerian abnormalities- 
1.  IOC = 3D USG 
2. Gold Standard - Laparoscopy + Hysteroscopy

Reference: DC Dutta's Textbook of Gynecology, 8th edition, Page no 37, 197.

questions.text: A resident is evaluating a patient, who presented with acute onset of chest pain and dyspnea, for pulmonary embolism. Which of the following imaging test should be performed to confirm this diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• Since CT pulmonary angiography is the primary imaging test (Investigation of choice)used to diagnose pulmonary embolism (PE), it should be carried out.
  • Echocardiograms for the majority of individuals with acute PE are normal. Nonetheless, echocardiography is a highly helpful diagnostic technique for identifying diseases including acute myocardial infarction, pericardial tamponade, and aortic dissection that can resemble PE.
  • As a second-line diagnostic procedure for PE, ventilation-perfusion (V/Q) scanning is typically utilized for patients whose CT results are unclear or who are unable to tolerate intravenous contrast.
  • Large proximal PE may be detected by MR pulmonary angiography, but smaller segmental and subsegmental PE cannot be reliably detected by this method. It is employed in situations where a ventilation-perfusion scan or CT angiography cannot be performed.
Reference: Harrison's principles of internal medicine 20th edition Page no 1912

questions.text: An infectious disease specialist is investigating a case of recurrent meningitis in a patient. The patient has a history of cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) leaks. Which bacterial species is commonly associated with recurrent meningitis in individuals with CSF leaks?
questions.solution:
The correct answer is 2. Pneumococci

  • Recurrent meningitis in individuals with cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) leaks is commonly associated with Streptococcus pneumoniae (pneumococci)
  • Pneumococci are a common cause of bacterial meningitis in general, and they are especially significant in individuals with CSF leaks. CSF leaks can occur after trauma, surgery, or as a result of congenital conditions. When the integrity of the dura mater is compromised, the risk of bacterial invasion increases, and pneumococci are particularly adept at colonizing these areas and causing infection.
  • Meningococci (Neisseria meningitidis), while a major cause of meningitis, are not strongly associated with CSF leaks as pneumococci.
  • Haemophilus influenzae was historically a more common cause of meningitis, particularly in children before the introduction of the Hib vaccine. However, it is now much less common due to widespread vaccination, and it is not specifically linked to recurrent meningitis in the context of CSF leaks.
  • Escherichia coli (E. coli) is a common cause of meningitis in neonates and immunocompromised individuals, but it is not typically associated with recurrent meningitis due to CSF leaks.

Therefore, pneumococci (Streptococcus pneumoniae) are the most likely bacterial species to cause recurrent meningitis in individuals with CSF leaks.


Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 227.

questions.text: A public health surveyor is collecting demographic data during a household visit. The household consists of a 35-year-old man, his 6-weeks-pregnant wife, their 3-year-old child, and the man's brother and his wife, who are visiting for a week. How would the surveyor classify this family structure based on its composition?
questions.solution:
• The correct answer is nuclear family.
  • A nuclear family consists of two parents and their children living together as a single household. In this case, the 35-year-old man, his pregnant wife, and their 3-year-old child form the core family unit. The presence of visiting relatives, the man's brother and his wife, does not change the classification, as they are temporary members of the household.
  • An extended family includes additional relatives such as grandparents, uncles, aunts, or cousins living permanently in the same household.
  • A joint family typically includes multiple generations or siblings living together permanently, sharing finances and responsibilities.
  • A third-generation family refers to a structure where three generations, including grandparents, parents, and children, live together, which is not the case here.

Since the core unit consists of two parents and their child, and the visiting relatives are not permanent members, this household is best classified as a nuclear family.

Reference: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Extended_family#:~:text=An%20extended%20family%20is%20a,the%20stem%20and%20joint%20families.

questions.text: A researcher is investigating the role of nitric oxide (NO) in regulating gastrointestinal function. What is the primary effect of NO on the smooth muscle of the digestive tract?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 3: Gastrointestinal smooth muscle relaxation

In peristalsis, segment before food bolus undergoes contraction and segment after the bolus undergoes relaxation. This complex movement propels food forwards.


 

Reference- Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology Edition 26 th Page no 485

questions.text: Which labeled structure (A, B, C, or D) is primarily involved in inspiration?
questions.solution:
In the given image -
A- Phrenic nerve
B- Vagus nerve
C- Sympathetic chain
D- Recurrent laryngeal nerve

Phrenic nerve innervates the diaphragm (C3-C5). The diaphragm descends during inspiration causing expansion of the rib cage. Exhalation causes the diaphragm to rise. The phrenic nerve can be seen in the photograph as the nerve in front of the Scalene anterior muscle.

Reference: Gray's Anatomy The Anatomical Basis Of Clinical Practice Edition 42 nd Page no 1042-1044

questions.text: Public health officials are discussing a previous influenza pandemic. Which influenza strain caused the pandemic declared in 2009?
questions.solution:
• The correct answer is H1N1.
  • The 2009 influenza pandemic, commonly referred to as swine flu, was caused by the H1N1 strain of the influenza A virus. The outbreak began in April 2009 and was officially declared a pandemic by the World Health Organization in June 2009.
  • H5N1 is known as avian influenza or bird flu, primarily affecting birds with sporadic human infections but has not led to a pandemic.
  • H7N7 is another avian flu strain that has caused some human infections but was not responsible for the 2009 pandemic. H3N3 is a strain of influenza A that has caused seasonal flu outbreaks but was not responsible for the 2009 pandemic.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 509

questions.text: A patient undergoing a surgical procedure requires muscle relaxation. The anesthesiologist chooses a non-depolarizing neuromuscular blocking agent that undergoes spontaneous degradation in the body. Which drug is most likely being used?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Atracurium

Atracurium is rapidly eliminated by Hoffman elimination and thus can be given in a patient with liver or kidney dysfunction.

* [Extra Edge]: Hofmann elimination

  • This refers to inactivation of the drug in the body fluids by spon­taneous molecular rearrangement without the agency of any enzyme.
  • Atracurium’s disappearance from the body depends on hydrolysis of the ester moiety by plasma esterases and by a spontaneous or Hofmann degradation (cleavage of the N-alkyl portion in the benzylisoquinoline). Hence, two routes for termination of effect are available, both of which remain functional in renal failure
Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 32.

questions.text: A 14-year-old girl presents with seizures, hypopigmented macules on her trunk, and facial angiofibromas. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The correct answer is tuberous sclerosis.

Tuberous sclerosis is a genetic neurocutaneous disorder characterized by seizures, hypopigmented macules (ash-leaf spots), and facial angiofibromas. It is caused by mutations in the TSC1 or TSC2 genes, which regulate cell growth.



Other options
  • Neurofibromatosis type 1 presents with café-au-lait spots, neurofibromas, axillary freckling, and optic gliomas but does not include hypopigmented macules or facial angiofibromas.
  • Sturge-Weber syndrome features a port-wine stain on the face, leptomeningeal angiomas, and seizures but lacks ash-leaf spots and angiofibromas.
  • Von Hippel-Lindau syndrome is associated with retinal and cerebellar hemangioblastomas, renal cell carcinoma, and pheochromocytomas but does not present with seizures, hypopigmented macules, or facial angiofibroma
Ref: Rooks Textbook of Dermatology 9th edition • Page 801 - 807

questions.text: An epidemiologist is lecturing on the concept of chronic carrier states in infectious diseases, where individuals can harbor and transmit pathogens for extended periods, even without showing symptoms. Which of the following diseases does NOT typically have a chronic carrier state?
questions.solution:
• Measles does not have a chronic carrier state.
  • Once a person recovers from measles, they do not carry or spread the virus.
  • Diseases like typhoid, gonorrhea and diphtheria, however, can have chronic carriers who can continue to spread the disease even after they recover.
Extra Edge- Iceberg phenomenon is not seen in measles, tetanus and rabies. 


Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 166.

questions.text: A tissue sample is examined under a microscope. Cells show shrunken shape, but the cell contents are intact and and there is no inflammation. Which of the following is not a feature in the above process?
questions.solution:
• The correct answer is lysosomal enzymatic digestion.
  • The described scenario suggests apoptosis, as the cells exhibit shrinkage, intact cell contents, and no inflammation. Apoptosis is programmed cell death that maintains plasma membrane integrity, preventing an inflammatory response.
  • Lysosomal enzymatic digestion is a feature of necrosis, not apoptosis. In necrosis, lysosomal enzymes break down cellular components, leading to membrane rupture and inflammation. 
  • Apoptosis features present in this scenario include caspase activation, as apoptosis is mediated by caspases, which trigger a cascade leading to controlled cell death.
  • Apoptosis may be physiological, occurring in processes such as embryonic development and immune cell regulation, or pathological in cases of DNA damage or infections.
  • In Apoptosis- plasma membrane remains intact, preventing leakage of cellular contents and inflammation.



Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of disease, 10th Edition, Page No 41-44.

questions.text: A 24-year-old woman presents to a reproductive endocrinologist with a history of recurrent pregnancy loss. She has been trying to conceive for four years without success. Imaging studies reveal a uterine anomaly diagnosed as a septate uterus, where a fibrous band of tissue divides the uterine cavity. Which surgical procedure is considered the most effective treatment for a septate uterus, offering the best chance of improving reproductive outcomes?
questions.solution:
• Hysteroscopic septum resection is now the procedure of choice for management of uterine septum as it doesn't involve any abdominal incision. 
  • Historically, metroplasty for a septum was performed by laparotomy via the Jones or Tompkins procedure, which involved excising a wedge of the uterine fundus containing the septum or opening the fundus and incising the septum. Strassmann metroplasty is used for bicornuate uterus.

Mullerian Anamolies




Reference: Shaw's Textbook of Gynaecology, 17th edition, Page no 72.

questions.text: A psychiatrist is assessing a patient's cognitive function using the Mini-Mental State Examination (MMSE). Which of the following core mental domains is primarily evaluated by the MMSE?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 2. Cognition
 
  • The Mini-mental state examination(MMSE) is a 30-point questionnaire that is used extensively in clinical and research settings to measure cognitive impairment.
  • It is a screening tool for dementia. It assesses cognitive functions. The total score in MMSE is 30.
  • A score less than 27 suggests Mild Cognitive Impairment (MCI) and less than 24 is suggestive of Dementia.




Reference: Kaplan and Sadock's Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Page no 201, 233, 1344.

Linear IgG deposition in the dermo-epidermal junction
