questions.text: A 30-year-old male patient presents with flaccid bullae (fluid-filled blisters) on an erythematous (reddened) base, along with erosions on his oral mucosa. A skin biopsy is taken for immunofluorescence studies to determine the underlying cause of these lesions. What pattern of immunoglobulin deposition would be most consistent with this diagnosis ?
questions.solution:
• Flaccid bullae with an erythematous foundation and erosions over the oral mucosal membrane point towards a diagnosis of Pemphigus vulgaris.
  • Fishnet IgG deposition in the epidermis is seen in the case of Pemphigus vulgaris.
  • Biopsy typically shows acantholysis and an intraepidermal blister( suprabasal split).
Fish net appearance in DIF (in Pemphigus Vulgaris)



Difference between Pemphigus Vulgaris and Bullous Pemohigoid



Reference- Rook's Textbook of Dermatology, 9th edition, Page number 50.2, 50.8

questions.text: A 58-year-old woman has right iliac fossa pain that is dull and painful. Upon examination, a tumour (mass) in the right iliac fossa could be felt and there was a noticeable gross pallor. Which diagnosis is most likely?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 4: Carcinoma ascending colon
 
  • In a 58-year-old woman with right iliac fossa pain, a tumor palpable in the region, and noticeable gross pallor, the most likely diagnosis is carcinoma of the ascending colon (Option D).
  • Right-sided colonic tumors, particularly in the ascending colon, can present with nonspecific symptoms such as abdominal pain and weight loss. This patient
  • The palpable mass and gross pallor could be indicative of an advanced stage of colon cancer.
  • Further investigations, such as colonoscopy and imaging studies, would be required to confirm the diagnosis.


Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 1358.

questions.text: Which drug elicits the following response on blood pressure and heart rate as shown in the given image?
questions.solution:
The image depicts an increase in systolic pressure, diastolic pressure, mean arterial pressure, and reflex bradycardia, which is characteristic of the action of norepinephrine.

Norepinephrine stimulates α1 receptors leading to an increase in peripheral vascular resistance and β1 receptors causing an increase in stroke volume. As a result, both diastolic and systolic pressures rise, along with the mean arterial pressure. This elevation in mean arterial pressure triggers a reflex bradycardia through baroreceptor-mediated mechanisms.

Other options
  • Epinephrine action is more on beta recepator > alpha receptors - this would results in increase in systolic BP, HR but fall in diastolic blood pressure and peripheral vascular resistance. Mean BP would be slightly raised 
  • Isoproterenol is pure beta receptor agonist - will lead to significant increase in systolic BP, HR but fall in diastolic blood pressure and peripheral vascular resistance leading to significant fall in Mean BP. 



Reference- KDT Edition 8 pg no 124.

questions.text: A patient undergoing long-term antibiotic therapy complains of tinnitus and difficulty hearing. Which of the following antibiotics is LEAST likely to be the cause of these symptoms?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is Option 3 - Metronidazole

Metronidazole is not an ototoxic drug. Rest all drugs are known to induce hearing loss. 



Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 895.

questions.text: A virologist is setting up a laboratory to quantify the amount of virus in patient samples. Which of the following techniques is the most appropriate and accurate method for estimating viral load?
questions.solution:
Viral load can be estimated by Real Time PCR. It is used for quantification of DNA.

This is done by taking a sample of known viral concentration (available commercially) and running a series of 10x dilutions on the same protocol and recording the resulted CT (cycle threshold) with each known level of viral load for that specific test, run in that particular way.

Reference: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry, 32nd Edition, Page no 453.

questions.text: A female presented with excessive daytime sleepiness and impaired concentration and memory for one year. On examination, the BMI was 43 kg/m2 and BP was 170/98 mmHg. ABG was done in awake state and the findings are given below. Which of the following is the likely diagnosis? PaO2: 70 mmHg PaCO2: 53 mmHgHCO3: 33 mmHg
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of an obese patient experiencing daytime sleepiness and hypercapnia on arterial blood gas (ABG) suggests obesity hypoventilation syndrome (OHS) aka Pickwickian syndrome. OHS arises due to factors such as increased work of breathing, respiratory muscle impairment due to the added load, and a decreased central ventilatory response to hypoxemia and hypercapnia. The diagnosis of OHS requires the following criteria:
- A BMI of > 30 kg/m2
- A PaCO2 of > 45 mmHg, indicating daytime alveolar hypoventilation
- Evidence of sleep-disordered breathing, often due to obstructive sleep apnea (OSA)

Other Options

Obstructive sleep apnea (OSA) (option A)
Obstructive sleep apnea (OSA) does not cause chronic daytime hypercapnia. OHS often coexists with OSA, but hypercapnia in the awake state confirms OHS.
OHA is diagnosed if the patient exhibits either symptoms of nocturnal breathing disturbances or daytime sleepiness, with 5 or more episodes of obstructive apnea or hypopnea per hour of sleep. Each episode should last at least 10 seconds, leading to a >3% drop in oxygen saturation or brain cortical arousal. OSA is diagnosed using an overnight polysomnogram (PSG). 

Central sleep apnea (CSA) (option D) is caused by an increased sensitivity to PCO2, resulting in an unstable breathing pattern characterized by periods of hyperventilation alternating with apnea. A prolonged circulation delay between the pulmonary capillaries and carotid chemoreceptors also contributes to CSA, often seen in patients with heart failure. These patients may present with Cheyne-Stokes breathing.

Narcolepsy (option C) presents with difficulty in maintaining wakefulness and disrupted nocturnal sleep. However, unlike sleep apnea, patients with narcolepsy typically feel well-rested upon awakening but become tired throughout the day. A distinguishing feature of narcolepsy is cataplexy—sudden muscle weakness without loss of consciousness, usually triggered by strong emotions.
 

Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page no 209,2203-2206 .

questions.text: An obese male patient presents with right upper quadrant pain and mildly elevated liver enzymes (AST/ALT). An ultrasound examination reveals grade 2 hepatic steatosis (fatty liver). The patient reports moderate alcohol consumption (2-3 drinks per week). What is the most appropriate initial management strategy for this patient ?
questions.solution:
The given history of Obesity + <5 drinks per week +elevated AST and ALT is suggestive of Non alcoholic Fatty liver disease.

First line management for NAFLD is Lifestyle modifications and weight loss (Aim for 5–10% total body weight reduction) and Vitamin E(most potent antioxidant).  

Non alcoholic fat liver disease is associated with diabetes and obesity the fatty change may also be caused due to the effect of toxins proteins malnutrition dyslipidemia and anorexia. Methotrexate, doxycycline  is other drugs causing hepatitis steatosis.

Reference: Harrison’s Principals of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page No 2622.

questions.text: A forensic anthropologist is examining skeletal remains to estimate the age of an individual. Which ossification center of the clavicle is the last to fuse and is therefore a reliable indicator of skeletal maturity, often used in legal contexts to assess eligibility for marriage?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1. Sternal End

The legal age for marriage for girls and boys is 18 and 21 respectively.
Clavicle's secondary ossification center at the sternal end appears at 19-20 years of age(~2 years earlier in females) and is used to certify bone age for marriage. 

Ossification centers of Clavicle
Site of Appearance              Time of                      Appearance     Time of Fusion
Two primary centers (medial/lateral)    5-6 weeks in utero       45th day of             Intrauterine life
Secondary center at Sternal(medial) end.    19-20 years (2    years earlier in females)         25th Year
Secondary center at Acromial end            20 year       Immediately

Reference: THE ESSENTIALS OF FORENSIC MEDICINE AND TOXICOLOGY, Dr. K.S. NARAYAN REDDY, 34th Edition, Page No 62.

questions.text: A reproductive biologist is explaining the process of spermatogenesis to students. During which specific stage of spermatogenesis does the independent assortment of maternal and paternal chromosomes occur?
questions.solution:
In spermatogenesis, independent assortment of paternal and maternal chromosomes occurs during meiosis I, in which primary spermatocyte (2n) is converted into two secondary spermatocytes (n).

Meiosis I separates pairs of homologous chromosomes, reduces the cell from diploid to haploid, hence is also called as reductional division.

The other stages are not directly associated with independent assortment:

  • Spermatogonia to primary spermatocyte: This is the stage where spermatogonia (diploid) undergo mitosis to form primary spermatocytes. There is no independent assortment here because mitosis does not involve the separation of homologous chromosomes.

  • Secondary spermatocyte to spermatids: This stage involves meiosis II, which is similar to mitosis and separates sister chromatids. Independent assortment has already occurred in meiosis I.

  • Spermatids to spermatozoa: This is the process of spermiogenesis, where spermatids undergo morphological changes to become mature spermatozoa, but there is no further chromosome segregation here.



Reference: Langman' Medical Embryology Edition 14 th page no 16,17

questions.text: An MRCP image is shown below. Which among the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The MRCP image in question reveals several round filling defects within the common bile duct and the common bile duct (CBD) appears dilated suggesting choledocholithiasis. Choledocholithiasis, or stones in the common bile duct, is often asymptomatic but can cause biliary colic or obstructive jaundice. Treatment typically involves ERCP with or without sphincterotomy, followed by laparoscopic cholecystectomy.

Reference: Sabiston Textbook of Surgery, 20th Edition, page no 1494-1497 .

questions.text: What is the likely diagnosis for the displayed image?
questions.solution:
The given image depicts Uterocervical prolapse. 

STAGING OF UTERINE PROLAPSE



PICTORIAL REPRESENTATION OF STAGES OF UTERINE PROLAPSE



Other options:
2. Decubitus ulcer will have a punched out lesion.
3. Vulval cancer will show a fungating growth over the vulva. 


Reference: Shaw's Textbook of Gynaecology, 17th edition, Page no 289, 290.

questions.text: An anatomist is describing the unique features of certain muscle attachments. Which of the following muscles or tendons has an intracapsular course within a synovial joint, meaning it passes through the joint capsule itself?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1:  Long Biceps Tendon
 
  • The long biceps tendon is located in the shoulder joint, specifically in the intertubercular groove of the humerus.
  • It is part of the biceps brachii muscle, which has two tendons - the long head and the short head. The long head of the biceps tendon travels within the shoulder joint and has a synovial sheath that allows it to move smoothly and reduce friction during joint movement.
  • Inside the shoulder joint, the long biceps tendon has additional synovial, intracapsular tissue because of its sheath, which is not present in the other structures listed.




 

Reference: Gray's Anatomy The Anatomical Basis Of Clinical Practice Edition 42 nd Page no 917

choices.text: Give another dose of Anti-D 72 hours postpartum depending on the baby blood group
Give another dose of Anti-D 72 hours postpartum irrespective of baby blood group
No need of additional dose since she is ICT negative

questions.text: A pregnant woman who is Rh-negative receives anti-D immunoglobulin (RhoGAM) at 28 weeks of gestation as standard antenatal prophylaxis. Her indirect Coombs test (ICT) is negative at this time. What is the recommended management regarding further anti-D administration after delivery?
questions.solution:
Give another dose of Anti-D 72 hours postpartum depending on the baby blood group

In RAADP ( Routine antenatal Anti D Prophylaxis) , anti D is administered at 28 weeks and then within 72 hours post partum if the baby is Rh positive. If the baby is Rh-negative, no further dose is needed.
 
  • Fetomaternal hemorrhage at delivery accounts for as many as 90 percent of alloimmunization cases.
  • Routine postpartum administration of anti-D immune globulin to at-risk pregnancies within 72 hours of delivery lowers the alloimmunization rate by 90 percent. Additionally, provision of anti-D immune globulin at 28 weeks gestation reduces the third-trimester alloimmunization rate.
  • Whenever there is doubt whether to give anti-D immune globulin, it should be given.
Reference: Williams Obstetrics, 26th edition, Page no 356, 357.

questions.text: A developmental biologist is studying the process of testicular descent during fetal development. At what gestational age does the trans-inguinal phase of testicular descent typically occur, where the testes migrate through the inguinal canal?
questions.solution:
Correct option is 3: 28 weeks.

Testis develop in retro-peritoneum from genital ridge.
Pull of the gubernaculum, differential growth of abdominal wall and hormonal factors play an important role in the decent.

Undescended testes: when the normal path of descent gets arrested. Most common site is the inguinal canal.
Biphasic descent of testes:
1. Transabdominal- completes by 8th week of gestation
2. Trans-inguinal or Inguinoscrotal- Begins at 26th week and ends at 33rd week of gestation.

Chronology of decent of testes:





PS Just for laughs. 

Reference: Titi-Lartey OA, Khan YS. Embryology, Testicle. [Updated 2023 Apr 24]. In: StatPearls [Internet]. Treasure Island (FL): StatPearls Publishing; 2024 Jan-. Available from: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK557763/

choices.text: Trophozoites in stool are essential for clinical diagnosis

questions.text: Which of these is incorrect with respect to amoebic liver abscess?
questions.solution:
The correct answer is:

1. Trophozoites in stool are essential for clinical diagnosis

Explanation:

  • Amoebic liver abscess is caused by Entamoeba histolytica, a protozoan parasite. While Entamoeba histolytica infection typically begins in the intestines and may cause dysentery, the presence of trophozoites in stool is not always essential for diagnosing amoebic liver abscess. In fact, the liver abscess may develop without overt intestinal symptoms or the presence of trophozoites in the stool. Diagnosis is more often confirmed through imaging (e.g., ultrasound or CT scan) and serology (antibody testing)or aspiration of the abscess revealing "anchovy sauce" pus rather than stool examination.

Other options:

  • Maybe asymptomatic: This is true. Many people with Entamoeba histolytica infection, including those with liver abscesses, can be asymptomatic or have only mild symptoms. Some individuals may have no gastrointestinal symptoms, even though they develop a liver abscess.

  • More common in males than females: This is true. Amoebic liver abscess is more commonly seen in males than females, often in young adult males.

  • Rarely affects brain, eye, and skin: This is also true. While Entamoeba histolytica primarily affects the intestines and liver, it rarely spreads to other organs such as the brain, eyes, or skin. This type of extra-intestinal spread, when it occurs, is uncommon.

Therefore, the incorrect statement is 1. Trophozoites in stool are essential for clinical diagnosis, because stool examination alone is not always definitive for diagnosing an amoebic liver abscess.
 

Reference: Paniker's Textbook of Medical Parasitology, 8th edition, Page no 21.

questions.text: A pediatrician is assessing a child for malnutrition using the World Health Organization (WHO) criteria. Which of the following anthropometric measurements is included in the WHO criteria for defining severe acute malnutrition (SAM) in children?
questions.solution:
The World Health Organization (WHO) defines severe acute malnutrition (SAM) as any of the following conditions for children between the ages of 6 and 59 months:

1. A weight that is less than three standard deviations (SD) of the WHO Child Growth Standards for length (or height).
2. Bilateral edema is seen.
3. A circumference around the mid-upper arm (MUAC) of less than 11.5 cm.

To summarize, a MUAC of less than 11.5 cm is indicative of SAM.



Reference -Ghai Essential Pediatrics 9th Edition - Page no. 97

questions.text: A woman experiencing infertility is discussing treatment options with her reproductive endocrinologist. The physician suggests a minimally invasive surgical procedure called ovarian drilling. In which of the following conditions is ovarian drilling often performed as a therapeutic intervention?
questions.solution:
• Laparoscopic ovarian drilling is a surgical procedure used for the management of Polycystic Ovary Syndrome (PCOS).
  • Ovarian drilling is a minimally invasive laparoscopic procedure performed in women with PCOS-related infertility who are resistant to first-line ovulation induction treatments like clomiphene citrate or letrozole.
PCOS
1. PCOS is an endocrine disorder commonly found in women of reproductive age and can affect multiple body systems.
2. The Rotterdam criteria are utilized for diagnosing PCOS, requiring the presence of any two of the following three components for a definitive diagnosis:
  • Clinical or biochemical hyperandrogenism (e.g., hirsutism, acne)
  • Menstrual abnormalities, such as oligomenorrhea, amenorrhea, anovulation, and infertility
  • Polycystic ovaries on ultrasound examination or sonographic criteria for polycystic ovaries include the presence of more than 20 follicles and/or an increased ovarian volume greater than 10 mL, or both.
Management of PCOS:
  • Weight reduction and lifestyle changes (such as smoking cessation) are recommended.
  • Oral contraceptive pills (OCPs) are commonly prescribed to address menstrual irregularities, as well as to reduce acne and hirsutism.
  • Anti-androgens like Letrozole are effective for treating hirsutism, with OCPs containing cyproterone acetate often prescribed for patients experiencing hirsutism.
  • Many patients with PCOS are prone to insulin resistance, which can be managed with metformin. Acarbose may be used if metformin is not tolerated.
  • For patients presenting with infertility, clomiphene citrate is typically the first-line treatment for inducing ovulation, often in combination with dexamethasone and letrozole. If they fail - Laparoscopic ovarian drilling may be tried.
Reference - https://www.reproductivefacts.org/news-and-publications/fact-sheets-and-infographics/ovarian-drilling-for-infertility/

questions.text: A cardiologist is reviewing an electrocardiogram (ECG) showing distinct changes in the ST segment and T wave morphology. The ECG displays prominent waves marked in the image, which are small, rounded deflections following the T wave. These ECG findings are characteristic of which electrolyte imbalance?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: Hypokalemia
 
  • The image shows U wave.
  • U waves are small deflections that can appear on an electrocardiogram (ECG) following the T wave and before the next P wave.
  • U waves are often prominent and can be seen in leads V2 to V4 on the ECG.
  • U waves can be seen in certain conditions such as hypokalemia (low potassium levels), which is the most common cause.
  • Hyponatremia (low sodium levels) and hypercalcemia (high calcium levels), do not typically cause U waves in an ECG.


Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 1830, 1831.

questions.text:
A 26-year-old male presents to the dermatology clinic with well-demarcated, erythematous plaques covered with silvery scales on the extensor surfaces of his elbows and knees.



 Examination of his nails reveals small depressions, known as pitting. What is the most likely diagnosis based on these characteristic findings?
questions.solution:
The presence of erythematous plaques with silvery scales on the extensor surfaces of the arms, along with punctate pitting of the nails, strongly indicates psoriasis.

Psoriasis is a chronic inflammatory skin condition that may have systemic implications. The most common form is plaque psoriasis.
  • The peak onset typically occurs between 16 to 22 years and again between 57 to 62 years. Patients often report itching and present with a papulosquamous rash.
  • The lesions are characterized by their red and scaly appearance, with well-defined borders from surrounding normal skin.
  • Sometimes, they are surrounded by a clear peripheral area known as the Woronoff ring.
  • Common locations for the lesions include the scalp, trunk, and extensor surfaces of the limbs.
  • The Koebner phenomenon (or isomorphic phenomenon) describes the formation of new lesions at sites of trauma, resulting in linear lesions.
  • Nail changes are frequently observed in all types of psoriasis. Patients may exhibit pits, ridges, and grooves on the nail plates. If the nail bed is affected, signs such as subungual oil drops, subungual hyperkeratosis, and distal onycholysis may occur.

The histopathological hallmark of psoriasis includes multiple neutrophilic foci in the parakeratotic stratum corneum (referred to as Munro's microabscesses) and spongiform neutrophils in the spinous layer of the epidermis (known as spongiform pustules of Kogoj).

Management primarily involves the topical application of steroids, retinoids, vitamin D, and emollients. Other treatment options may include phototherapy, along with systemic medications such as oral methotrexate, acitretin, and cyclosporine.

Other options- 

  • Eczema (Atopic Dermatitis): While eczema can cause red, inflamed patches, it typically appears on the flexural surfaces (e.g., behind the knees and elbows) rather than on the extensor surfaces. Eczema is also more likely to cause intense itching, and it does not usually present with silvery scales or nail pitting.

  • Pityriasis rosea: This condition often presents with a herald patch (a single, large, oval lesion) followed by a rash of smaller lesions arranged in a Christmas tree pattern. The plaques are not typically as thick or silvery as those seen in psoriasis, and there is no nail pitting.

  • Lichen planus: This condition presents with purple, pruritic, polygonal papules. It may involve the nails, but it does not usually cause the silvery scales or extensor surface involvement seen in psoriasis.

Reference - https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Psoriasis

questions.text: A pulmonologist is interpreting arterial blood gas (ABG) values in different clinical scenarios. In which of the following conditions is the partial pressure of oxygen in arterial blood (PaO2) NOT typically decreased?
questions.solution:
Correct option is 2: Congestive heart failure without Pulmonary edema
 
  • The partial pressure of oxygen (PaO2) is a measure of the amount of oxygen dissolved in the blood.
  • The question asks which of the given conditions does not cause a decrease in PaO2. Option 2, congestive heart failure without pulmonary edema, is the correct answer. In congestive heart failure (CHF), the heart’s pumping efficiency is reduced. Without pulmonary edema, there’s no fluid in the alveoli to impair gas exchange directly. If lung function remains normal and there is no pulmonary edema -ventilation-perfusion matching stays intact, PaO2 is not typically decreased
Other options
  • Option 1 - Restrictive lung disease: This includes conditions like pulmonary fibrosis or kyphoscoliosis, where lung expansion is limited. Reduced lung volume impairs gas exchange, leading to a lower PaO2 due to decreased alveolar ventilation and diffusion capacity. PaO2 is typically decreased.
  • Option 3-Obstructive lung diseases-conditions like COPD or asthma cause airflow limitation, leading to ventilation-perfusion mismatches and often hypoventilation. This reduces oxygen transfer into the blood, resulting in a decreased PaO2, especially in severe or chronic cases. PaO2 is typically decreased.
  • Option 4 - high altitude, refers to a condition where there is a decrease in the partial pressure of oxygen due to lower atmospheric pressure at high altitudes. This can lead to a decrease in PaO2 due to reduced oxygen availability.
Reference: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK545153/

questions.text: An audiologist is performing a hearing test that measures faint sounds produced by the ear itself. Where do these otoacoustic emissions originate?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 2: outer hair cells 

Otoacoustic emissions(OAE) begin at Outer Hair cells (OHC). OHCs are more prone to noise-induced trauma and ototoxicity. Hence, OAE is used to detect early noise-induced hearing loss, to differentiate between cochlear (OAE are present) and retro cochlear (OAE are absent) and to screen hearing in neonates as an objective test.

Reference : P L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck surgery , 7th Edition- page 29

questions.text: An oncologist is reviewing a biopsy report that describes a tumor arising from mesenchymal tissue, characterized by the production of osteoid (bone matrix). This type of malignant tumor, often affecting the bones of children and young adults, is classified as:
questions.solution:
Answer: 2. Osteosarcoma

The tumor described in the biopsy report, which arises from mesenchymal tissue and is characterized by the production of osteoid (bone matrix), is most likely an osteosarcoma. Osteosarcoma characteristically has osetoid matrix formation - involves long bones(femur/humerus) and has bimodal peak - one in adolescent age group and another in elderly(50-60y). X-ray shows Codman triangle formation. 

Other Options:

  • Fibrosarcoma: This is a malignant tumor that arises from fibrous tissue, not bone. It does not produce osteoid
  • Undifferentiated sarcoma: This is a broad and less specific term that refers to a group of malignant tumors that do not show clear differentiation toward a particular tissue type. It does not specifically involve osteoid production
  • Malignant peripheral nerve sheath tumor: This is a malignant tumor originating from nerve sheath cells and does not produce osteoid.
Reference :https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK560759/

questions.text: During a pathology lecture, a student makes a statement about apoptosis. Which of the following statements is INCORRECT?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Cell swelling

  • Cell size is reduced, the cytoplasm is dense and eosinophilic, and the organelles, although relatively normal, are more tightly packed.
  • This contrasts with necrosis, in which an early feature is cell swelling, not shrinkage.

Morphologic features of Apoptotic cell
 
  • Cell shrinkage- Cell size is reduced, the cytoplasm is dense and eosinophilic, and the organelles although relatively normal, are more tightly packed. This contrasts with necrosis, in which an early feature is cell swelling, not shrinkage.
  • Chromatin condensation- This is the most characteristic feature of apoptosis. The chromatin aggregates peripherally, under the nuclear membrane, into dense masses of various shapes and sizes. The nucleus itself may break up into two or more fragments.
  • Formation of cytoplasmic blebs and apoptotic bodies- The apoptotic cell first shows extensive surface membrane blebbing, which is followed by fragmentation of the dead cells into membrane bound apoptotic bodies composed of cytoplasm and tightly packed organelles, with or without nuclear fragments.
  • Phagocytosis of apoptotic cells or cell bodies, usually by macrophages- The apoptotic bodies are rapidly ingested by phagocytes and degraded by the phagocyte’s lysosomal enzymes.
  • In H&E-stained tissue, the apoptotic cell appears as a round or oval mass of intensely eosinophilic cytoplasm with fragments of dense nuclear chromatin.
 

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 43.

choices.text: Teriparatide can be used in this case
Bisphosphonates not given for more than a year
Oral Vit D3 given along with Oral calcium

questions.text:
Back pain is being reported by a 60-year-old female who has previously experienced Cole's fracture. -2.6 is the DEXA Score.
In regards to this patient's treatment, which of the following statements is false?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is of Osteoporosis. 
  • It is recommended that bisphosphonates be taken for at least three to five years, and in some cases, longer.
  • However, it is important to monitor the patient for any potential side effects, such as osteonecrosis of the jaw or atypical femur fractures.
  • Teriparatide (PTH Analogue) is another drug used to treat osteoporosis but is usually reserved for patients with severe osteoporosis or those who have not responded to other treatments.
  • Calcium and vitamin D supplementation are also important in the treatment of osteoporosis to support bone health.
  • The recommended daily intake of calcium for adults over the age of 50 is 1200mg, and vitamin D supplementation is  recommended if the patient's levels are low.
Reference- Textbook of Orthopedics by John Ebnezar fourth edition Page no 671,672

choices.text: Inject ether to dissolve the balloon and pull it out
Inject water to over distend the balloon until it bursts and Foley's can be removed
Use ultrasound guidance to locate and prick the balloon and then remove the catheter

questions.text: Following a surgical procedure, a surgeon instructs an intern to remove a patient's Foley catheter. The intern attempts to deflate the catheter's balloon but encounters resistance, and the catheter cannot be removed. The surgeon also attempts removal without success. What is the most appropriate next step in managing this difficult catheter removal?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 4: Use ultrasound guidance to locate and prick the balloon and then remove the catheter
 
  • When unable to remove a Foley's catheter, the next step would be to use ultrasound guidance to locate and puncture the balloon, allowing for deflation and subsequent removal of the catheter.
  • Injecting ether (option B) or water (option C) to dissolve or over-distend the balloon is not recommended as it may cause potential complications or damage to the urethra or bladder. CT-guided rupture (option A) is an invasive and unnecessary procedure with radiation exposure that should be avoided.


Reference: SRB's Manual Of Surgery, Sriram Bhat M, 6th Edition, Page No 991.

questions.text: A patient presents to a physical therapist complaining of shoulder pain. After a thorough examination, the therapist diagnoses supraspinatus tendinitis, an inflammation of the supraspinatus tendon, one of the rotator cuff muscles. The therapist asks the patient to actively abduct their arm (raise it out to the side). Within what range of motion is pain most likely to occur in a patient with supraspinatus tendinitis?
questions.solution:
In a patient with supraspinatus tendinitis, pain is most likely to occur during the "painful arc" range of shoulder abduction, which is typically between 60 degrees and 120 degrees. This is due to the mechanics of the shoulder and the role of the supraspinatus muscle, one of the rotator cuff muscles.

Reason

  • The supraspinatus tendon assists in initiating and stabilizing shoulder abduction, particularly in the early range. However, between 60° and 120° of abduction, the tendon passes beneath the acromion (part of the shoulder blade), where it can be compressed or impinged, especially if inflamed (as in tendinitis). This impingement causes the characteristic pain during this range, often peaking around 90°.

  • Below 60°, the tendon is less compressed, and pain may be minimal or absent. Beyond 120°, the humeral head has typically cleared the acromion, reducing impingement and often alleviating pain, though this depends on the severity of inflammation.


     

Reference:Apleys system of Orthopaedics and Fractures 10th edition page no 343

questions.text: A patient presents to a dermatology clinic with multiple skin lesions on their forearm. The lesions are hypopigmented (lighter than the surrounding skin), have diminished sensation (hypoesthesia), and are surrounded by a slightly raised, erythematous border. Microscopic examination of a skin biopsy reveals granulomatous inflammation and the presence of numerous AFB -acid-fast bacilli. What is the most likely diagnosis based on these clinical and histopathological findings?
questions.solution:
Lepromatous leprosy is a form of leprosy which is characterized by multiple hypo-aesthetic and hypopigmented macules on the skin.

 

Reference- Rook's Textbook of Dermatology, 9th edition, Page number 28.8

questions.text: A cytogeneticist is trying to determine the precise location of a specific gene on a chromosome. They need a technique that can pinpoint the exact position of the gene within the chromosome's structure. Which of the following methods is most suitable for determining the precise location of a genomic locus?
questions.solution:
Exact location of a genetic loci is identified by Fluorescent in-situ hybridization (FISH).
FISH, which uses fluorescent rather than radioactively labeled probes, is a very sensitive technique for determining the exact location of a genetic loci.
This frequently places the gene on a given band or region of the chromosome.
 

Other options:

  • Polymerase chain reaction (PCR): PCR is used to amplify specific DNA sequences, but it does not provide information about the location of a gene on a chromosome. It is primarily used for detecting or amplifying a target sequence, not for mapping genes to specific chromosomal locations.

  • Chromosome painting: This technique uses fluorescently labeled DNA probes to stain entire chromosomes or large regions of chromosomes, often to visualize large structural rearrangements or chromosome abnormalities. While useful for detecting large chromosomal changes, it does not provide the fine resolution needed for pinpointing the exact location of a single gene.

  • Comparative genomic hybridization (CGH): CGH is used to detect chromosomal gains or losses (e.g., amplifications or deletions) across the entire genome. It helps identify genomic imbalances but does not provide precise information on the exact location of a gene.



Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathology,10th edition, Page no 165.

questions.text: A neurosurgeon is reviewing a brain scan showing a lesion impacting the floor of the third ventricle. Which of the following structures is NOT located on the floor of the third ventricle?
questions.solution:
• The third Cranial nerve (Oculomotor) does not form the floor of the third ventricle although it lies in close relation to the floor.
  • Floor of Third Ventricle Formed by
1. Optic Chiasma
2. Infundibular recess
3. Tuber cinerium
4. Mammillary bodies
5. Posterior perforated substance
6. Tegmentum of the midbrain.



 

Reference: Gray's Anatomy The Anatomical Basis Of Clinical Practice Edition 42 nd Page no 409

questions.text: A patient exhibits visual agnosia, hypersexuality, and hypermetamorphosis following bilateral temporal lobe damage. While evaluating for Kluver-Bucy syndrome, which of the following is NOT typically associated with this condition?
questions.solution:
• Visual agnosia, hypersexuality, hyperorality and hypermetamorphosis(excessive attention to visual stimuli) are characteristics of Kluver-Bucy syndrome.
  • However, intractable seizures are not seen in this. 
  • Kluver-Bucy Syndrome (KBS) is a rare neurological disorder caused by damage to the medial temporal lobes of the brain.
  • The condition is characterized by hypersexuality, oral behaviors such as hyperoralism and pica, and an overall lack of fear.
Reference: Kaplan and Sadock's Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Page no 14, 518.

questions.text:
The value of Va / Q becomes zero when

1. Partial pressure of O2 becomes zero
2. No exchange of O2 & CO2 is taking place
3. Partial pressure of CO2 alone becomes zero
4. Partial pressure of both CO2 and O2 is normal
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 2

No exchange of O2 & CO2 is taking place V/Q = 0 is seen in airway obstruction. V/Q = ∞ is seen in blood flow obstruction. The ratio of pulmonary ventilation to pulmonary blood flow for the whole lung at rest is about 0.8. If the ventilation to an alveolus is reduced relative to its perfusion, the PO2 in the alveolus falls because less O2 is delivered to it and the PCO2 rises because less CO2 is expired. Conversely, if perfusion is reduced relative to ventilation, the PCO2 falls because less CO2 is delivered and the PO2 rises because less O2 enters the blood.
 

Reference- Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology Edition 26 th Page no 639

questions.text: The following lab results were obtained from a 60-year-old woman with a history of rheumatoid arthritis: Hb 4.5 g/dL, platelet count 2Lac/mm3, TLC 6000/mm3, serum ferritin 300 mg/L, and TIBC 220 ng/L. Which diagnosis is most probable amongst the following given options?
questions.solution:
• The Most probable diagnosis is anemia of chronic disease (ACD).
  • The patient has rheumatoid arthritis, a chronic inflammatory condition commonly associated with ACD.
  • Lab findings suggest ACD.
  • Low Hb (4.5 g/dL) indicates anemia.
  • Normal platelet count and TLC suggest no bone marrow suppression or severe hemolysis.
  • High serum ferritin (300 mg/L) is typical of ACD due to inflammation(Ferritin being an acute phase reactant - it rises with inflammation), whereas it is low in iron deficiency anemia.
  • Low TIBC (220 ng/L) is characteristic of ACD, unlike iron deficiency anemia, where TIBC is increased.
  • ACD is characterized by block in delivery of iron from the reticuloendothelial system to the erythroid progenitors due to upregulation of Hepcidin thus inhibiting Ferroportin.

Other options

  1. Iron deficiency anemia would show low ferritin and high TIBC, which is not the case here.
  2. Thalassemia minor usually presents with microcytosis and normal or elevated RBC count, and ferritin levels are typically normal.
  3. Autoimmune hemolytic anemia (AIHA) would present with high reticulocyte count, low haptoglobin, and high LDH, which are not mentioned here.

Thus, anemia of chronic disease is the most likely diagnosis.




Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page no 751, 753.

questions.text: A medical toxicologist is discussing methods for enhancing the elimination of toxins from the body. One such method is forced diuresis, where increased urine production is induced to flush out certain substances. This technique can be combined with manipulation of urine pH (acidification or alkalinization) to further enhance elimination. For which of the following toxins is alkaline diuresis commonly employed to facilitate its removal from the body?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Phenobarbitone

Alkaline diuresis with sodium bicarbonate 1 mEq/kg IV with or without mannitol is helpful only in the case of long-acting barbiturates which are eliminated primarily by renal excretion.
As phenobarbitone is acidic drug, forced alkaline diuresis helps in elimination of the drug. Other mentioned drugs - amphetamines/PCP/theophylline- are all basic in nature and hence, alkaline diuresis would not be useful. 

Other Acidic drugs for which alkaline diuresis is used include
1. Aspirin (Acetyl salicylic acid)
2. Methotrexate
3. Chlorpropamide

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 427.

questions.text: A public health official is explaining the Navjaat Shishu Suraksha Karyakram (NSSK). Which specific population group is the target of the NSSK interventions?
questions.solution:
The Navjaat Shishu Suraksha Yojna focuses on training healthcare professionals—including doctors, nurses, and Auxiliary Nurse Midwives (ANMs)—in essential newborn care (i.e neonates), early diagnosis, and effective management of common childhood ailments.

Note: Navjat in Hindi means - nav (new) - jaat - (born)  hence - newborn

Reference- Ministry of Health and Family Welfare (MoHFW), Government of India website.

choices.text: 95% of test results could have occurred by chance
Not more than 5% of the people benefitted by the drug could be due to chance
95% of patients will be benefitted by giving the drug

questions.text: A researcher claimed to have found a novel medication that has a p value of less than 0.05 and is helpful in treating chronic hypertensives. Which of the following statements about this is accurate?
questions.solution:
P value depicts the probability of obtaining a result just by chance p< 0.05 means that the probability of obtaining the result purely by chance is less than 5%.

CONFIDENCE LEVEL = 1-p

For a study to be statistically significant:- p has to be less than 0.05/5% or Confidence levels more than 0.95/95%
  • According to the given clinical vignette ,the study is statistically significant since the p value is given as <0.05
  • P < 0.05 means that less than 5% of the people benefitted by the drug is by chance.
Therefore, option 3 is the most appropriate answer to this question.

Option 4 (95% of patients will be benefitted by giving the drug) is incorrect interpretations of the p-value and statistical significance.

Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 979.

questions.text: Identify the image given below:
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1. Marbling

The given image shows Marbling.

Marbling of Skin refers to the mosaic like pattern on the skin which is seen at vein coverage due to production of H2S gas by the bacteria which combines with Hb present in the blood to form a greenish blue compound called Sulf-met-hemoglobin. It is usually seen ~ 36 hours since death.

Reference: THE ESSENTIALS OF FORENSIC MEDICINE AND TOXICOLOGY, Dr. K.S. NARAYAN REDDY, 33rd Edition, Page No 166.

questions.text: A young patient presents to an orthopedics clinic with complaints of right hip pain and difficulty walking. The physician orders an X-ray of the hip, which reveals a generalized increase in bone density, giving the bones a uniformly dense and opaque appearance, as shown in the image. Based on this characteristic radiographic finding, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• Osteopetrosis, also known as Albers-Schönberg disease or marble bone disease, is an uncommon hereditary disorder that results from defective osteoclasts
  • Bones become sclerotic and thick, but their abnormal structure actually causes them to be weak and brittle.
  • The given pelvic radiograph in question stem demonstrates bone within bone sign of osteopetrosis. 

Other options:

  • Osteoporosis: This condition involves decreased bone density and increased fragility, making bones more susceptible to fractures. It appears as bone thinning or porosity on X-rays, which is the opposite of the dense, opaque appearance seen in osteopetrosis.

  • Osteopoikilocytosis: This is a rare, benign condition characterized by multiple small, round areas of increased bone density (often described as bone islands), typically seen in the long bones, pelvis, and other skeletal regions. However, the findings are usually focal rather than generalized and do not result in the widespread uniformity of density seen in osteopetrosis.

  • Osteogenesis imperfecta: This condition is a connective tissue disorder that results in brittle bones, but it typically manifests with bone fragility and fractures rather than increased bone density. X-rays may show fractures or bowing of bones, but the bone density is not increased.

Reference-: Essential Orthopaedics by Maheshwari Edition 7th Page no 317

questions.text: A pregnant woman with a 2-year-old child gives a history of completing required antenatal vaccinations during her previous pregnancy. Which of the following would you recommend for her current pregnancy?
questions.solution:
In the scenario where a mother was vaccinated in her previous pregnancy two years ago, a booster dose of the Td (tetanus and adult diphtheria) vaccine is recommended during the current pregnancy.

Key Points on Td Vaccination in Pregnancy:
Purpose: To prevent neonatal and maternal tetanus.

For previously unimmunized women:
  • They should receive two doses of Td.
  • The first dose is given as early as possible during pregnancy.
  • The second dose should be given at least 1 month after the first and at least 3 weeks before delivery to allow time for antibody development.
  • For previously immunized women:
If they received 2 doses of Td during a prior pregnancy within the last 3 years, only a booster dose is needed.
The Td vaccine has replaced the use of the tetanus toxoid (TT) vaccine for all age groups, including pregnant women.

Reference - https://nhm.gov.in/images/pdf/programmes/maternal-health/guidelines/sba_guidelines_for_skilled_attendance_at_birth.pdf

choices.text: Conjunctival congestion with follicles, papillary hyperplasia and progressive pannus

questions.text: A patient with a confirmed diagnosis of leprosy undergoes a comprehensive ophthalmological evaluation. The examination reveals lagophthalmos and iris atrophy. Which of the following ocular findings is NOT typically associated with leprosy?
questions.solution:
Leprosy can cause lagopthalmos I.e inability to close the eyelids due to environment of zygomatic branch facial nerve. Decreased corneal sensation seen in leprosy is due to the involvement of ophthalmic branch of trigeminal nerve.

Other features seen are:
  • Keratitis with thickened, beaded corneal nerves, punctate subepithelial lesions, pannus, and vascularization
  • Chronic low-grade anterior uveitis
  • Miosis
  • Iris atrophy
  • Iris pearls
  • Retinal pearls.
  • Lacrimation, scanty mucoid discharge and foreign body sensation.
Conjunctival congestion, follicles papillary hyperplasia, Herbert follicles (seen in the limbal area), and progressive pannus are the characteristic features of trachoma, not of Leprosy. 

Reference: Comprehensive Ophthalmology, A.K. Khurana, 7th Edition, Page No 169.

questions.text: A patient suffering from intractable pain, unresponsive to conventional analgesics, is being considered for a neurosurgical intervention. Experimentally, which area of the brain can be stimulated to achieve pain control in such cases?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: Periaqueductal grey matter 
 
  • The periaqueductal gray (PAG) is a small area of gray matter located in the midbrain, near the cerebral aqueduct.
  • Descending pathways from the mesencephalic periaqueductal gray matter inhibit transmission in nociceptive pathways.
  • This descending pathway includes a synapse in the ventromedial medulla (Raphe nucleus) and the release of endogenous opiates. So periaqueductal gray matter releases endogenous opiate, thereby reducing intractable pain.
Other options:
  • Mesencephalon, subthalamic nucleus, and medial forebrain bundle, are all structures in the brain that are involved in functions, such as: Movement, cognition, and motivation.
  • However, there is no evidence that stimulation of these structures is effective in controlling pain.
Reference: Deep brain stimulation of the periaqueductal gray releases endogenous opioids in humans.” https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC5312788/

questions.text: A patient who overindulged in alcohol the previous evening and dozed off on an armchair arrives at the emergency room. His hand is immobile in the morning and radial nerve palsy is identified as the cause. What level of management comes after that?
questions.solution:
The correct next step is 1. Wait and Watch

Explanation:

  • This patient likely has Saturday night palsy, a radial nerve palsy caused by prolonged compression of the nerve against a hard surface while sleeping (often due to alcohol intoxication).

  • The most common type of nerve injury in this scenario is neurapraxia, which is a temporary conduction block without axonal damage.

  • Most cases recover spontaneously within 6-8 weeks, making observation the best initial approach.

Other options

  • Knuckle Bender Splint (Option 2) → This is used for ulnar nerve palsy (claw hand) and is not appropriate for radial nerve palsy. Instead, a wrist drop splint (cock-up splint) may be used for support, but it's not the primary treatment.

  • Immediate Surgery (Option 3) → Not needed unless there is a fracture, penetrating trauma, or no recovery after 3-6 months, which is not the case here.

  • EMG Study after 2 days (Option 4) → EMG/NCS is typically done after 3-4 weeks if no improvement is seen. Conducting it too early may not yield meaningful results.

Reference-: Essential Orthopaedics by Maheshwari Edition 7th Page no 71,64

choices.text: Hemorrhage on the posterior surface of the esophagus
Definitive sign of death due to manual strangulation
Caused by leakage of blood from venous plexus after death

questions.text: Except for ______, each of the following statements regarding the Prinsloo Gorden Artefact is accurate.
questions.solution:
The correct option is 3. "Definitive sign of death due to manual strangulation."
  • The Prinsloo Gorden Artefact is a hemorrhage on the posterior surface of the esophagus, which was first described by Prinsloo and Gordon.
  • However, it is not a definitive sign of death due to manual strangulation.
  • The Prinsloo Gorden Artefact is a post-mortem finding that is commonly seen in cases of manual strangulation. It is caused by the rupture of the small veins in the mucosa of the posterior wall of the esophagus due to the pressure applied during the act of strangulation.
  • The hemorrhage appears as a linear or crescent-shaped mark on the posterior wall of the esophagus and is usually located between the level of the cricoid cartilage and the bifurcation of the trachea.
  • While the presence of the Prinsloo Gorden Artefact is highly suggestive of death due to manual strangulation, it is not a definitive sign.
  • Other causes of the hemorrhage, such as forceful vomiting or resuscitation attempts, can also result in the appearance of the artefact.
Reference: Pollanen MS. Pitfalls and Artifacts in the Neck at Autopsy. Acad Forensic Pathol. 2016 Mar;6(1):45-62. doi: 10.23907/2016.005. Epub 2016 Mar 1. PMID: 31239872; PMCID: PMC6474509.

questions.text: An 8-year-old pre-pubertal girl presents with vaginal discharge. Upon examination, no signs of infection or trauma are noted. What is the most likely cause of the discharge?
questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario the girl is prepubertal and no signs of infection hence it's a case of non-specific vulvo-vaginiotis. 
  • Vulvovaginitis is an inflammation of the vulva and vaginal tissues . 
  • This is common problem in prepubertal girls. 
  • It is typically not caused by a specific pathogen and is not treated with antibiotics. 
  • It can also be caused by infection, irritation, a  foreign body, allergy, or systemic disease.
  • Physiological leucorrhea is more common in puberty due to hormonal changes.
  • Bacterial vaginosis and sexually transmitted diseases are less likely in pre-pubertal girls.


Reference: Shaw's Textbook of Gynaecology, 17th edition, Page no 333.

questions.text: A gynecologist is reviewing a Pap smear report for a female patient. The Pap smear image, shown below, reveals the presence of numerous organisms with characteristic flagella and a pear-shaped morphology. What is the most likely cause of this patient's vaginal infection based on the Pap smear findings?
questions.solution:
The given pap smear shows Actinomycetes. Identified cytologically as ball-like clusters of bacteria, with radiating filaments.
• ‘Cotton-ball’ clusters: Tangled clump of filamentous organisms, with acute angle branching
• Radial distribution of filaments or irregular ‘wooly body’ appearance (also known as “Gupta bodies”)
• Inflammatory perinuclear halo may be seen.
• Masses of leukocytes adherent to micro-colonies of the organisms with swollen filaments or ‘clubs’ at the periphery.

Other options: -
1. Candida- will show ger tube formation
2. HSV- Multinucleated giant cells mainly in Tzanck smear
3. Trichomonas- pear shaped cells with lancet nucleus seen.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 400.

choices.text: Pleocytosis with low protein and low sugar
Pleocytosis with high protein and low sugar
Lymphocytosis with low protein and low sugar
Lymphocytosis with high protein and low sugar

questions.text: Which of the following CSF findings is associated with Pneumococcal meningitis ?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 2: Pleocytosis with high protein and low sugar
  • Pneumococcal meningitis is a bacterial infection. The characteristic CSF findings of which are pleocytosis with high protein and low sugar.
Other options-
  • Pleocytosis with low protein and low sugar is seen in viral infections.
  • Lymphocytosis is seen in TB and similar conditions.
Pneumococcal meningitis
  • Pneumococcal meningitis is a type of bacterial meningitis caused by the bacteria Streptococcus pneumoniae.
  • In this condition, the bacteria infect the meninges (the protective membranes that cover the brain and spinal cord) and cause inflammation. This inflammation leads to an increase in the number of white blood cells and Neutrophils in the CSF, which is called pleocytosis.
  • Additionally, the bacteria produce toxins that damage the blood-brain barrier, which is a specialized system of cells that regulates the movement of substances between the blood and the brain.
  • This damage leads to an increase in the amount of protein in the CSF, which is called hyperproteinemia.
  • However, the bacteria also consume glucose (sugar) present in the CSF as a source of energy, leading to a decrease in the glucose level, which is called hypoglycorrhachia.
  • This decrease in glucose level is an important diagnostic feature of pneumococcal meningitis and is seen in most cases.
  • Therefore, the correct CSF finding associated with Pneumococcal meningitis is pleocytosis with high protein and low sugar, which is option 2.




Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 677.

questions.text: A young woman presents to her gynecologist complaining of lower abdominal pain that has been present for the past month. She also reports experiencing mild intermenstrual bleeding and painful urination (dysuria) accompanied by a scant vaginal discharge, which resolved spontaneously within a week. She discloses a history of multiple sexual partners. Given her symptoms and sexual history, what is the most likely causative organism for her pelvic inflammatory disease (PID)?
questions.solution:
This female is most likely to suffer from pelvic inflammatory disease.
  • The most common cause of PID is sexually transmitted diseases (STD), with gonococcal and chlamydial infections being the most common.
  • While chlamydial infection is often subacute and remains undiagnosed, Neisseria gonorrhoeae infection frequently presents as acute PID, as in this patient.

Reference: William’s Gynecology, 4th Edition, Page. No- 68.

questions.text: A neonatologist is attending to a newborn with a congenital heart defect. In which of the following cyanotic congenital heart conditions is the immediate administration of prostaglandin E1 (PGE1) crucial for maintaining ductal patency and ensuring adequate blood flow?
questions.solution:
• The correct answer is Tetralogy of Fallot with Pulmonary Atresia (TOF with PA)
  • Prostaglandin E1 (PGE1) is crucial in cyanotic congenital heart defects where systemic or pulmonary blood flow depends on a patent ductus arteriosus (PDA).
  • Tetralogy of Fallot with Pulmonary Atresia (TOF with PA) is a severe form of TOF where the pulmonary valve and artery are completely absent or occluded. In this condition, pulmonary blood flow depends entirely on the PDA because there is no direct connection between the right ventricle and the pulmonary circulation. PGE1 keeps the PDA open, ensuring blood reaches the lungs for oxygenation.

Other options
 
  1. Truncus arteriosus – The pulmonary arteries arise from a common trunk, so pulmonary blood flow is not dependent on the PDA. PGE1 is not necessary.
  2. ASD (Atrial Septal Defect) – This is a non-cyanotic defect and does not require PDA patency. PGE1 is not needed.
  3. VSD (Ventricular Septal Defect) – Most VSDs allow left-to-right shunting, providing pulmonary blood flow without PDA dependency. PGE1 is not necessary.

Reference-Ghai Essential Pediatrics 9th Edition Page no 423,424

questions.text: Varicose veins were discovered in a bus driver. Eczema of the skin and lipodermatosclerosis were discovered during investigation. He would fall within the following categories in the CEAP classification scheme:
questions.solution:
CEAP: Clinical, Etiologic, Anatomical & Pathophysiologic manifestation classification is used for chronic venous disorders.
Changes in skin and subcutaneous tissue secondary (skin eczema and Lipodermatosis) due to chronic venous disease (varicose vein) is classified as C4 as per CEAP classification.




Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 1030.

choices.text: Acetylcholine is released at the nerve terminal
Calcium is pumped back into the sarcoplasmic reticulum during relaxation
Calcium is released from sarcoplasmic reticulum during contraction
Calcium binds to tropomyosin to initiate muscle contraction

questions.text: Which of the following statements is incorrect about excitation-contraction coupling?
questions.solution:
• Calcium binds to Troponin C, not to the tropomyosin, to initiate muscle contraction. This binding exposes the Actin binding sites present on the myosin band which were earlier guarded by the tropomyosin helix.
E-C coupling proceeds as follows:
  1. The membrane potential of a skeletal muscle cell is depolarised by an action potential (e.g. from synaptic activation from an alpha motor neuron - this requires acetylcholine as the neurotransmitter)
  2. This depolarisation activates voltage-gated DHPRS (dihydropyridine receptors)
  3. This activates RyR type 1 via physical linkage As the RyRs open, calcium is released from the SR into the local junctional space, which then diffuses into the bulk cytoplasm to cause a calcium transient rise.
  4. The calcium released into the cytosol binds to Troponin C by the actin filaments, to allow cross-bridge cycling, producing force and, in some situations, motion.
  5. The sarco/endoplasmic reticulum calcium-ATPase (SERCA) actively pumps calcium back into the SR. As calcium declines back to resting levels, the force declines and relaxation occurs.

Reference- Ganong’s Review of Medical Physiology Edition 26 th Page no 104

questions.text: A female patient presents with a history of pelvic pain and discomfort. During laparoscopic surgery, the surgeon identifies purulent material located in the rectouterine pouch (cul-de-sac) and posterior cleft disruption. What will be the next step of management?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 1. Drainage of Pelvic Abscess
 
  • The presence of purulent material in the rectouterine pouch (cul-de-sac) and posterior cleft disruption strongly suggests a pelvic abscess, often secondary to pelvic inflammatory disease (PID), tubo-ovarian abscess, or a ruptured infectious collection.
  • The rectouterine pouch (pouch of Douglas) is the lowest point in the female peritoneal cavity, making it a common site for fluid accumulation, including pus in pelvic infections.
  • Surgical or percutaneous drainage is necessary to prevent further complications like sepsis or peritonitis.

TREATMENT of Pelvic Abscess: 

  • General: Systemic antibiotics should cover anaerobic as well as aerobic microorganisms (broad spectrum): Cefoxitin 1–2 g IV every 6–8 hours and gentamicin 2 mg/ kg IV per 24 hours and metronidazole 500 mg IV 8 hourly are started. Antibiotic regimen may have to be changed depending upon the sensitivity report.
  • Surgery: Posterior colpotomy is the definitive surgery to drain the pus through posterior fornix. The loculi should be broken with finger.

Reference: DC Dutta's Textbook of Gynecology, 8th edition, Page no 143.

questions.text: A medical student is learning how to measure blood pressure using a sphygmomanometer and stethoscope (auscultatory method). They are trying to understand the relationship between the Korotkoff sounds and the different phases of blood pressure measurement. Which Korotkoff sound phase corresponds to the diastolic blood pressure reading?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 4: Phase-5
 
  • While measuring the blood pressure in the Auscultatory Method we inflate the cuff until a reasonable pressure such that blood stops flowing through the artery.
  • Now as the cuff is deflated the pressure falls and bloods again starts flowing back through the artery . This produces a series of sounds called KOROTKOFF SOUNDS which can be described under various stages as depicted by the table given below :-

 

Reference- Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology Edition 26 th Page no 531

questions.text: A respiratory physiologist is studying the relationship between alveolar ventilation and arterial partial pressure of carbon dioxide (PaCO2) under conditions of constant arterial partial pressure of oxygen (PaO2). The graph depicts this relationship (line A) at a normal pH of 7.4. If the pH decreases to 7.3, indicating acidosis, in which direction will the line shift?
questions.solution:
• Chemoreceptors become even more sensitive in acidosis. Thus, a pH decrease results in a further shift to the left. There is higher alveolar ventilation (Denoted by line D) at a lower PCO2 due to the high sensitivity of chemoreceptors to low pH (acidosis) 
  • B and C denote changes due to hypoxia (pO2) - B occurs when pO2 decrease, and C when pO2 increases. A is the baseline. 
  • When both hypoxia and acidosis occur together - alveolar ventilation increase maximum - denoted by line E.
      

Reference: Ganong’s Review of Medical physiology, 26th Edition- Page no 651,652  .

questions.text: A 25-year-old pregnant woman presents with thrombocytopenia (low platelet count of 50,000/cc) and fragmented red blood cells observed on a peripheral blood smear. These findings raise concern for a thrombotic microangiopathy (TMA). Which of the following conditions is the LEAST likely differential diagnosis in this pregnant patient, considering her presentation?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 4: Evan's syndrome 


The patient presents with thrombocytopenia (platelet count 50,000/µL) and fragmented red blood cells (schistocytes), which are hallmark findings of thrombotic microangiopathy (TMA). The most common TMAs in pregnancy include:

  • Thrombotic Thrombocytopenic Purpura (TTP) – Caused by ADAMTS13 deficiency, leading to excessive platelet aggregation and microangiopathic hemolytic anemia.
  • Disseminated Intravascular Coagulation (DIC) – Associated with pregnancy complications like placental abruption, sepsis, and amniotic fluid embolism, leading to widespread clotting and bleeding.
  • HELLP syndrome (Hemolysis, Elevated Liver enzymes, Low Platelets) – A severe form of preeclampsia that causes microangiopathic hemolysis and thrombocytopenia.
SCHISTOCYTES

 

Why not Evan's syndrome

  • Evan’s syndrome is an autoimmune disorder characterized by immune thrombocytopenia (ITP) and autoimmune hemolytic anemia (AIHA).
  • It does not cause schistocytes (fragmented RBCs) or microangiopathic hemolytic anemia (MAHA), which are key features of TMA.
  • It is not typically associated with pregnancy-related thrombocytopenia or life-threatening microangiopathy.
 


Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page no 905, 907.

questions.text: A patient is rushed to the emergency room after a bee sting, presenting with significant facial swelling, intense itching, and dangerously low blood pressure (hypotension). These symptoms are characteristic of a severe allergic reaction (anaphylaxis). Which specific immunoglobulin (Ig) is primarily responsible for mediating this type of hypersensitivity reaction?
questions.solution:
Immunoglobulin E (IgE) is the key mediator in Type I hypersensitivity reactions, as suggested by the given clinical features. Immediate (Type I) hypersensitivity, also known as allergies or allergic reactions, is a rapid immunologic response triggered when an antigen binds to IgE antibodies on mast cell surfaces in a previously sensitized individual. These reactions are caused by environmental antigens, or allergens, which induce strong Th responses and IgE production in genetically susceptible individuals.

T-helper (TH) cell activation is mediated by IL-4, leading to the production of IL-4, IL-5, and IL-13. These cytokines stimulate IgE production and activate eosinophils by acting on B cells. IgE then binds to the Fcε receptor (FcεRI), coating mast cells. Upon reexposure to the allergen, cross-linking of IgE and FcεRI occurs, activating mast cells and leading to the release of potent mediators such as histamine, proteases, prostaglandins, leukotrienes, and cytokines like TNF and IL-1, along with chemokines.

The clinical presentation can vary from mild symptoms, such as allergic rhinitis, to severe, life-threatening anaphylaxis. Type I hypersensitivity occurs in two phases:

  • Immediate phase: Characterized by vasodilation, vascular leakage, smooth muscle spasm (as seen in asthma), and glandular secretions. These changes occur within minutes of allergen exposure and typically subside within a few hours.
  • Late-phase reaction: Marked by the infiltration of tissues by neutrophils, basophils, and eosinophils.

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 10th edition, pages 205-208.

questions.text: A microbiologist is working to identify a bacterial species from a patient sample. They need to determine if the bacteria can ferment lactose. Which culture media should they use to differentiate lactose fermenters from non-lactose fermenters?
questions.solution:
MacConkey agar is a selective and differential medium used to differentiate lactose fermenters, which appear pink, from non-lactose fermenters, which remain colorless or pale.

Selectivity and Differential Nature:
Selective: The medium contains bile salts and dyes that inhibit the growth of gram-positive organisms and gram-negative cocci.
Differential: The presence of a pH indicator allows for the identification of lactose fermentation; when lactose is fermented, the pH indicator turns pink-red.

Contents of MacConkey Agar:
Mnemonic: PLANT

Peptone
Lactose
Agar
Neutral red
Taurocholate sodium

Color Reactions:
Lactose-fermenting organisms (e.g., E. coli): Produce a pink color due to acid production from lactose fermentation.
Non-lactose fermenting organisms (e.g., Shigella sp., Salmonella sp.): Do not change the color of the medium, remaining colorless or pale.

Other options:

  • Sabouraud Dextrose Agar:

    • This is primarily used for fungi (especially yeasts and molds) and is not suitable for differentiating lactose fermentation in bacteria.
    • Not useful for lactose fermentation testing.

  • Thayer-Martin agar:

    • This is a selective medium used to isolate Neisseria species, particularly Neisseria gonorrhoeae. It does not have a component for distinguishing lactose fermenters.
    • Not useful for lactose fermentation testing.

  • Bile salt agar:

    • This medium contains bile salts, making it selective for enteric bacteria (e.g., enterococci), but it does not differentiate between lactose fermenters and non-fermenters.
    • Not the best choice for lactose fermentation differentiation.


Reference - https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK557394/#:~:text=MacConkey%20(1861%2D1931).,based%20on%20their%20lactose%20metabolism.

questions.text:
What is HAGMA seen with?

a. DKA
b. Lactic acidosis
c. Ethylene glycol poisoning
d. Renal Tubular Acidosis
questions.solution:
Correct option: 1. a,b,c are correct

RTA shows Normal AG metabolic acidosis (NAGMA)

Causes of HAGMA: [Mnemonic: MUDPILES]

1. Methanol
2. Uremia
3. Diabetic ketoacidosis
4. Phenformin, Paraldehyde
5. INH, Iron
6. Lactic acid
7. Ethanol, Ethylene glycol
8. Salicylates

Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 361.

questions.text: A young male patient with a known history of dyslipidemia and a confirmed mutation in the ABCA-1 gene presents for a follow-up appointment. Physical examination reveals enlarged, orange-yellow tonsils, as shown in the image. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Enlarged and yellowish/ Orange tonsils are pathognomonic of Tangier's disease.
 

Tangier disease is a rare autosomal recessive disorder caused by mutations in the ABCA1 gene. The ABCA1 protein is critical for the transport of cholesterol and phospholipids to apolipoprotein A-I (ApoA-I), which is essential for the formation of high-density lipoprotein (HDL). 

Key features of Tangier disease:

 
  • Extremely low or absent HDL cholesterol levels ("hypoalphalipoproteinemia").
  • Accumulation of cholesterol in various tissues, leading to enlarged, orange-colored tonsils, hepatosplenomegaly, and peripheral neuropathy.
  • Increased risk of atherosclerosis despite low levels of circulating cholesterol.
Reference: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry, 31st edition, Page no 258.

questions.text: A 65-year-old male with a history of chronic kidney disease presents with fatigue and shortness of breath. Blood work reveals an elevated creatinine and decreased bicarbonate. His acid-base status is most likely:
questions.solution:
The patient with CKD likely has metabolic acidosis. CKD causes Metabolic acidosis by the following mechanisms.

  • Decreased Excretion of Hydrogen Ions:  

    The kidneys are responsible for excreting excess H+ ions into the urine. In CKD, there is a reduction in the number of functioning nephrons, which decreases the kidney's capacity to excrete these ions. As a result, H+ accumulates in the bloodstream, leading to acidosis.

  • Impaired Bicarbonate Reabsorption:

    Normally, the kidneys reabsorb bicarbonate from the urine. In CKD, the reabsorption capacity is impaired, leading to a decrease in serum bicarbonate levels. This results in a reduced buffering capacity for H+ ions in the blood.

  • Increased Production of Organic Acids:

    CKD can also be associated with an increased production of organic acids (such as lactic acid) due to metabolic derangements. The accumulation of these acids contributes further to the acidotic state.

  • Loss of Ammonium Excretion:

    The kidneys also produce ammonium (NH4+) as a means of excreting H+ ions. In CKD, the ability to synthesize and excrete ammonia is diminished, leading to less H+ excretion and further acid retention.

    •  

Reference-Ghai Essential Pediatrics 9th Edition Page no 83

questions.text: A patient with a complex inguinal hernia undergoes surgical repair involving the placement of a large mesh prosthesis in the pre-peritoneal space. Which surgical technique was most likely used?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 3: Stoppa operation
 
  • The open pre-peritoneal large mesh repair for complex inguinal hernia is known as the Stoppa operation.
  • It involves creating a pre-peritoneal space and placing a large mesh in this space to provide support and reinforcement to the weakened abdominal wall.
  • The mesh is positioned behind the transversalis fascia, covering the potential spaces where hernias can occur.



Reference: Sabiston Textbook of Surgery, The BIOLOGICAL BASIS of MODERN SURGICAL PRACTICE, 21st Edition, Page No 1125.

choices.text: Conflicts generated from new opportunities arising from societal trends
Is concerned with psychology of individuals living in the society
Changes in disease pathology due to social factors

questions.text: What does social pathology deals with?
questions.solution:
Social pathology is a field that examines how social conditions and structures influence health, disease, and deviant behaviors in a society. It studies the impact of factors like poverty, inequality, urbanization, and cultural changes on disease patterns and social problems.

Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 788.

choices.text: Hepatorenal syndrome may occur in upto 50% of patients

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true about leptospirosis ?
questions.solution:
Rats are the prime reservoirs of Leptospira, the bacteria that cause leptospirosis - Hence option 1 is correct.

The other statements are incorrect:
  • Fluoroquinolones are not the first-line treatment(doxycycline or penicillin is more commonly used). Doxycycline is the DOC. 
  • Person-to-person transmission is very rare
  • Hepatorenal syndrome does not occur in up to 50% of patients—though it can occur in severe cases, it's not that common.
Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 338.

questions.text: Which of the following tests will confirm the diagnosis in a patient with asthmatic clinical symptoms?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 3: Diurnal variation in PEF > 10 Percent
 
  • Asthma is characterized by variable airflow obstruction and airway hyperresponsiveness, which can be confirmed using different pulmonary function tests.
  • Diurnal variation in Peak Expiratory Flow (PEF) greater than 10 percent is a hallmark of asthma. Asthma symptoms tend to worsen at night and early morning, leading to fluctuations in PEF readings taken at different times of the day. A variation greater than 10 percent (or greater than 20 percent in some guidelines) suggests airflow variability, which is diagnostic of asthma.

Other options

  1. Increase in FEV1/FVC – Asthma causes obstructive lung disease, leading to a decrease in FEV1/FVC, not an increase.
  2. Greater than 20 percent increase in FEV1 after Methacholine – Methacholine challenge is used to detect airway hyperresponsiveness, but the diagnostic criterion is a greater than 20 percent decrease in FEV1 (not an increase).
  3. Reduction of FEV1 greater than 20 percent after bronchodilators – This is incorrect because bronchodilators improve airflow in asthma, leading to an increase in FEV1, not a decrease.



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2154, 2155.

questions.text: An ophthalmologist needs to perform a cycloplegic refraction on a child with strabismus (squint) to accurately assess their refractive error. Which cycloplegic agent is typically preferred for refractive testing in children with balance between efficacy and side effects?
questions.solution:
#controversial (Option 4> 1)

When refractive testing a child with a squint, the recommended medication is 1% cyclopentolate.
Atropine has the strongest cycloplegic effect  But because of the undesired side effects and risks from atropine, cyclopentolate has been found to offer a very effective cycloplegia even for moderate to high hyperopia and has become the standard of care for traditional pediatric cycloplegic exams
American Academy of Ophthalmology guidelines currently recommend cyclopentolate over atropine for children. 

Reference: Kanski's Clinical opthalmology:A systematic Approach,8e,pg- 162

questions.text: A 50-year-old female presents with an ovarian mass. A biopsy is performed. Statistically, what is the most likely type of ovarian tumor?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 1. Epithelial tumors
  • Epithelial tumors are the most common type of ovarian tumors, accounting for approximately 80-90% of all ovarian tumors.
  • These tumors arise from the surface layer of the ovary, which is composed of epithelial cells.
  • Epithelial tumors are further classified into different subtypes based on their histology, such as serous, mucinous, endometrioid, and clear cell tumors.
  • Germ cell tumors are rare tumors that arise from the germ cells of the ovary and account for only 5% of all ovarian tumors. These tumors are more common in younger women and are usually benign. However, some malignant germ cell tumors can also occur.
  • Sex cord-stromal tumors and fibrous stromal tumors are also rare types of ovarian tumors that arise from the supporting tissue of the ovary. Sex cord-stromal tumors account for only 1% of all ovarian tumors and can produce hormones such as estrogen and testosterone.
  • Fibrous stromal tumors, also known as fibromas, are benign tumors that arise from the connective tissue of the ovary.
