 Variable


Reference: Shaw's Textbook of Gynaecology, 17th edition, Page no 459, 460.

questions.text: A new drug for hypertension is being investigated. The initial study enrolls a small number of healthy volunteers to evaluate the drug's potential adverse effects and determine a safe dosage range. What phase of clinical trial is this?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Drug safety

Phase I: Human pharmacology and safety
The emphasis is on safety, tolerability, and to detect any potentially dangerous effects on vital functions, such as precipitous fall/rise in blood pressure or heart rate, arrhythmias, bronchospasm, seizures, kidney/liver damage, etc.

Unpleasant side effects are noted and an attempt is made to observe the pharmacodynamic effects in man. The human pharmacokinetic parameters of the drug are measured for the first time.

Although Dosing, Pharmacokinetics is also being carried out in Phase 1 but most appropriate answer would be Drug safety.



Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 90.

questions.text: A 25-year-old male patient presents with symptoms consistent with dengue fever. The physician orders blood tests and other investigations to assess the severity of the illness. Which of the following findings would indicate a higher risk of severe dengue and potential complications?
questions.solution:
Diagnosis of severe Dengue(anyone 1 of the following)

1. Severe Bleeding
2 Severe organ involvement- AST and ALT >1000, Dengue Encephalopathy, Myocarditis
3. Severe plasma leakage leading to Dengue Shock syndrome and capillary leak causing ARDS.

Reference: Nelson Textbook of Pediatrics, 21th Edition, Page. No- 1762.

questions.text: Following a total laryngectomy, a patient is undergoing speech rehabilitation. Which of the following techniques is NOT typically employed in this setting?
questions.solution:
After total laryngectomy, supraglottic prosthesis can’t be used as it can’t be fixed properly in the absence of larynx. Polite yawning is done in patients who have undergone laryngectomy as part of rehabilitation of olfaction. Voice rehabilitation can be done by two methods- Oesophageal speech and tracheo—esophageal prosthesis.( best technique for production of voice in a post laryngectomy patient.)


Reference : P L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck surgery , 7th Edition- page 352

questions.text: A neonatologist is concerned about a newborn exhibiting signs of sepsis. They are aware that neonatal sepsis can be caused by various bacterial organisms. What is the most common causative organism of neonatal sepsis in India, considering the local prevalence of bacterial pathogens?
questions.solution:
• Most common organism causing neonatal sepsis among the given options in India is Klebsiella.
  • Klebsiella is the most common organisms in both early and late sepsis in intramural and extramural births.
Reference -Ghai Essential Pediatrics 9th Edition Page no 160

questions.text:
A histologist is examining tissue samples from different organs and identifying specialized cell types. Match each cell type (a-d) with its corresponding location in the body (1-4):
 
a. Kupffer cells 1. Stomach
b. Parietal cells 2. Connective tissue
c. Histiocytes 3. Liver
d. Dust cells 4. Lungs
questions.solution:
• Kupffer cells are macrophages found in the liver (a-3).
  • Parietal cells are found in the stomach and secrete hydrochloric acid (b-1).
  • Histiocytes are a type of macrophage found in connective tissue (c-2).
  • Dust cells are macrophages found in the lungs, specifically in the alveoli (d-4)

Reference: Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology, 26th edition, Page no 449, 610.

questions.text: During an upper endoscopy, the endoscopist encounters resistance at 25 cm from the incisors. This corresponds to a normal anatomical constriction caused by which structure?
questions.solution:
The arch of the aorta and left bronchus cross the esophagus at approximately 25 cm from the upper incisor teeth.

Normal Constrictions of the Esophagus:
The esophagus typically exhibits three constrictions at specific levels, measured from the upper incisors:
  • Junction of the esophagus with cricopharynx: Located 15 cm from the incisor teeth.
  • Crossed by the arch of aorta and left bronchus: Located 25 cm from the incisor teeth.
  •  Piercing the diaphragm: Located 40 cm from the incisor teeth.

questions.text: A parasitologist is studying the different ways that parasitic organisms can infect human cells. Some parasites specifically target hepatocytes (liver cells). Which of the following parasites does NOT typically infect hepatocytes as part of its life cycle?
questions.solution:
Among the given options, Babesia does not infect hepatocytes. Rest of the organisms have a hepatocytic phase in their life cycle. 

Additional points about Babesia
 
  • Babesia is a parasite that resembles malaria but does not have hemozoin pigment. It directly invades RBC and doesnot invade hepatocytes. 
  • The white-footed mouse is a reservoir
  • It's spread by ticks (Ixodes)
  • Has Maltese cross appearance on PBS.




Reference: Paniker's Textbook of Medical Parasitology, 8th edition, Page no 86.

questions.text: A patient with a history of chronic alcohol abuse presents to the neurology clinic with confusion, ataxia (loss of coordination), and an inability to move his right eye outwards. Neurological examination reveals lateral rectus palsy (6th nerve palsy). Based on these findings, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A chronic alcoholic presents with the classic triad of: GOA
  • Global Confusion
  • Ataxia
  • Ophthalmoplegia(6th nerve palsy)
This is suggestive of Wernicke's encephalopathy caused by thiamine (vitamin B1) deficiency.

Other options:

  • 2. Korsakoff psychosis: Korsakoff syndrome typically occurs after Wernicke encephalopathy and is characterized by severe memory impairment and confabulation. It does not present with acute confusion, ataxia, and 6th nerve palsy as seen here. Korsakoff psychosis is more of a chronic sequela of thiamine deficiency.

  • 3. Delirium tremens: This is a severe withdrawal syndrome from alcohol, characterized by tremors, agitation, hallucinations, and autonomic instability (e.g., tachycardia, hypertension). It does not typically cause 6th nerve palsy or ataxia in the way that Wernicke encephalopathy does.

  • 4. De Clerambault syndrome: This is a psychotic disorder involving erotomania, where the patient believes another person (usually of higher social status) is in love with them. It does not present with confusion, ataxia, or 6th nerve palsy and is unrelated to alcohol abuse or thiamine deficiency.

Reference: Harrison’s Principals of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page No 2525, 3561.

questions.text: An ophthalmologist needs to measure the intraocular pressure (IOP) of a patient with an irregular corneal surface due to keratoconus or other corneal abnormalities. Which type of tonometer is specifically designed to accurately measure IOP in patients with irregular corneas?
questions.solution:
Tonometer used for irregular surface of the cornea is Mackay-Marg tonometer.
  • MacKay-Marg tonometer is useful in measuring IOP after keratoplasty and in scarred corneas in which Goldmann is not useful.

  • It works by minimizing the influence of corneal biomechanics and irregularities, providing a more accurate reading in these cases.

    Other options

  • Rebound tonometer (e.g., Icare) - Can be used in irregular corneas but is less accurate than Mackay-Marg in such cases.
  • Dreger's tonometer - Obsolete and rarely used in clinical practice.
  • Maklakov tonometer - A weighted-applanation tonometer influenced by corneal properties, making it less reliable in irregular corneas.
Reference:  Jain, Arun K MD; Sukhija, Jaspreet MS; Gupta, Amod MS. ProTon tonometer determination of intraocular pressure in patients with scarred corneas. Indian Journal of Ophthalmology 54(2):p 95-98, Apr–Jun 2006. | DOI: 10.4103/0301-4738.25829

questions.text: A radiologist is reviewing a chest X-ray that shows a rounded pulmonary nodule with a characteristic 'eggshell' calcification pattern. This pattern, where the calcification forms a thin layer around the periphery of the nodule, is most suggestive of which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
Correct option is 1: Silicosis.

Eggshell calcification: Fine calcification seen at the periphery of a mass.
The various conditions in which it is seen are as follows:
  • Silicosis
  • Post irradiation Hodgkin disease 
  • Coal workers' pneumoconiosis (CWP)
  • Sarcoidosis
  • Scleroderma



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page no 2169.

questions.text: A pathologist is examining a tissue sample taken from a healing wound. They are observing the inflammatory infiltrate and the various cells involved in the wound healing process. Which type of immune cell is typically the FIRST to arrive at the site of injury during wound healing, primarily through chemotaxis?
questions.solution:
Neutrophils are the first cells to emerge at the site of injury due to chemotaxis. While they begin appearing within 24 hours, their peak occurs on the second day of the inflammatory phase of wound healing.

Wound healing occurs in two distinct ways:

  1. Primary intention (Primary union): This type of healing occurs when an injury affects only the epithelium layer. A neatly sutured surgical incision is a common example of this process. The steps in primary union include:

    • The coagulation cascade is activated upon injury, leading to clot formation. This clot attracts growth factors, cytokines, chemokines, and migrating cells.
    • Neutrophils infiltrate the wound site within the first 24 hours.
    • By 24-48 hours, epithelial cells from both wound margins begin migrating and form a thin layer of epidermis over the wound.
    • On day 3, macrophages replace neutrophils, and granulation tissue starts forming.
    • By day 5, neovascularization reaches its peak.
    • In the second week, fibroblast proliferation and collagen deposition become prominent.
    • By the end of the first month, the wound is covered with a nearly normal epidermis, and the scar consists of cellular connective tissue with minimal inflammatory cells.

  2. Secondary intention (Secondary union): This process occurs when wounds heal without primary closure, usually in cases of larger wounds with significant tissue loss. The healing process is prolonged and involves more extensive granulation tissue formation and wound contraction.

Reference: Robbin's Pathologic basis of disease 9e page no 106-107

choices.text: Transferrin receptor 1 translation is decreased by binding to iron regulatory protein to 3-prime UTR
Transferrin receptor 1 translation is increased by binding to iron regulatory protein to 5-prime UTR
Ferritin translation is decreased by binding to iron regulatory protein to 5-prime UTR
Ferritin translation is increased by binding to iron regulatory protein to 5-prime UTR

questions.text: A cell biologist is studying the intricate mechanisms that regulate iron metabolism within cells. Iron regulatory proteins (IRPs) play a crucial role in sensing intracellular iron levels and controlling the expression of proteins involved in iron storage and uptake. Which of the following statements accurately describes the interaction between IRPs and mRNA, and its effect on iron metabolism?
questions.solution:
Option(3) is correct.

When iron concentration is low
  • IRP(iron regulatory protein) binds to the 3' IRE (iron responsive element) and stabilize the mRNA for Tfr (transferrin receptor), increasing its translation  and allowing Tfr synthesis. (Hence, option 1 is incorrect. Option 2 is incorrect because IRP does not bind to 5' UTR of Tfr)
  • IRP binds to 5' IRE of ferritin prevents mRNA to synthesise ferritin (i.e. decreases Ferritin translation) - therefore option 3 is correct. 
When iron concentration is High
  • IRP dissociate from 3' IRE on transferrin receptor and lack of IRP causes decreased Tfr synthesis.
  • IRP dissociate from 5'IRE of Ferritin to allow mRNA to synthesise ferritin.(ie increase Ferritin)(therefore option 4 is incorrect - ferritin translation is not increased by binding of IRP to 5')
Reference: Lippincott's Illustrated Reviews, 5th edition, Page no 458.

questions.text: A truck driver came with complaints of a painless indurated genital ulcer after unsafe intercourse. Which of the following can be used to diagnose the condition in a low-resource setting when an active ulcer is present?
questions.solution:
• The patient presents with a painless, indurated genital ulcer, which is highly suggestive of primary syphilis caused by Treponema pallidum.
  • In a low-resource setting, the best diagnostic method when an active ulcer is present is dark field microscopy, which directly visualizes the spirochetes from a lesion exudate.
  • While serological tests like VDRL and FTA-ABS are useful, they may not be readily available in all settings. Proper diagnosis and early treatment of syphilis are crucial to prevent complications and transmission.




Reference: Ananthanarayan and Panikers textbook of microbiology 10th edition page no
10-12,378-383,385,387.

questions.text: An orthopedic surgeon is treating a patient with a non-union fracture, a fracture that has failed to heal properly. Which of the following substances is commonly used as a bone graft substitute to stimulate bone growth and promote healing in cases of non-union?
questions.solution:
• Bone morphogenetic proteins are commonly used for bone formation in patients with non-union.
  • BMPs are a group of osteoinductive growth factors that stimulate the differentiation of mesenchymal stem cells into osteoblasts.
  • BMPs have been shown to be effective in promoting bone formation in non-unions.
Reference-: Essential Orthopaedics by Maheshwari Edition 7th Page no 85

questions.text: Which is the best test used for detection of malarial infection and to estimate parasite concentration?
questions.solution:
• Malarial parasite detection and parasite quantification is best done by a Giemsa-stained thick smear.
  • Microscopy is the best method for the diagnosis of malaria due high sensitivity and specificity. A diluted Giemsa stain is applied to both thick and thin films.
  • Thin smear is used to identify the particular infecting species of Plasmodium.
  • Thick smear is used to detect infection and estimate parasite concentration.

Reference: Park’s textbook of preventive and Social Medicine, 25th Edition, Page No 306.

questions.text: An Accredited Social Health Activist (ASHA) worker is reviewing her tasks and the corresponding financial incentives under the National Rural Health Mission (NRHM). Which of the following activities will NOT be financially compensated?
questions.solution:
Under the National Rural Health Mission (NRHM), ASHA workers receive financial incentives for various tasks related to maternal and child health, immunization, and community health services. However, administering the zero dose of DPT and OPV is not financially compensated because:

  • Oral Polio Vaccine (OPV) at birth is part of routine immunization, but ASHA workers do not administer vaccines; this is done by trained health workers (ANMs).
  • DPT is not given at birth; the first dose is scheduled at 6 weeks of age.

Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 701.

questions.text: An otolaryngologist is performing an emergency procedure to control severe epistaxis (nosebleed). They are considering various surgical approaches to ligate (tie off) bleeding arteries. Which of the following arteries is NOT typically ligated in the management of epistaxis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 3: Internal carotid artery

Internal Carotid artery doesn’t contribute to kiesselbach plexus in the nose

To Manage Epistaxis following steps are done in sequential order until the bleeding is controlled.
Step 1
Trotter’s or Hippocratic Method: Pinching the nose with thumb and index finger for 5 minutes while sitting and leaning forwards.

Step 2
Cauterisation with Electro Cautery if the bleeding point can be localized

Step 3
Anterior and Posterior nasal Packing

Step 4
Endoscopically ligating Sphenopalatine artery followed by Maxillary artery and if still not controlled then external Carotid artery


Reference : P L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck surgery , 7th Edition- page 201
